posts.title: How Writing a Blog Can Help You With Depression
posts.markdown: ![depression](https://www.statnews.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Depression_APStock72622943-1024x576.jpg) Battling depression is never easy and those who have experienced it firsthand know this much better than anyone else. Surprisingly, aside from the conventional methods of depression therapy available today, there are many more alternative techniques at one’s disposal when it comes to fighting depression. For someone not acquainted with writing, and blog writing in particular, it may seem unusual – even outright impossible, that writing can be a mean to combat depression. From this reason, our aim will be to show how writing your own personal blog can help you battle, and hopefully even overcome your depression. ## You Are No Longer Alone Depression is quite harder to handle when we are facing it alone. Here is where setting up your own blog helps you come out of your comfort zone into the wonderful world of online blogging. There are hundreds of thousands, perhaps even millions of people, who are blogging today and sharing their personal experiences to the public. Your blog helps you share your experiences with others so that you are no longer alone. ## Connect With Other People by Writing A Blog Many people have, at some point, had issues with depression. Many of them also shared their experiences with others. There are many personal blogs today where people talk about their [personal experiences at combating depression](http://www.healthline.com/health/depression/best-blogs-of-the-year#13). Creating your own blog gives you the opportunity to connect with people who have similar experiences and, more importantly, people who will understand and support you. ## Express Yourself A blog is your own internet diary. You should try and treat it just like you treat a handwritten personal diary. As we’ve said earlier, unlike a handwritten personal diary, a blog lets you connect with other people, but it is the process of expressing yourself through writing that is equally important. Sometimes, we cannot handle our emotions, experiences and memories and we lack the means to express them properly. Writing is one of the best method of expressing yourself. Don’t be afraid to transfuse your thoughts into your blog. ## Get Busy They say idleness is a soul-killer. This is especially true for depression which cannot be successfully overcome in idleness and loneliness. If you don’t have a job, you can treat your blog as your primary occupation and devout your time to writing and improving it. Giving yourself something to be preoccupied about is a great way of deflecting harmful thoughts. Consider setting up a daily schedule for posting new blog entries. Moreover, if you have audience following and commenting your blog posts, you will have a responsibility towards them. ## You Have a Purpose The lack of purpose is one of the leading causes behind depression. Finding motivation can be very hard, which is especially true if you have a job that does not fulfill you. A blog gives you a chance to do something you’re good at, and something that you genuinely care about. ## Artistic Freedom Anyone will tell you that the overwhelming feeling of freedom when writing is one of best things about being a writer. Writing a blog is no different in this regard, and you will have complete freedom at deciding what to blog about. [Art therapy](http://expandedconsciousness.com/2016/06/25/7-unusual-ways-deal-depression/) has been recognized as a proven method for combating depression. We have to emphasize that the quality of your writing is not of prime importance here. Even if it doesn’t look too good, this is not a reason to get worried or give up. Your writing is your therapy and you are doing it to get in touch with your inner being. With time and practice your writing skills will also improve. ## Explore Your Interests Writing is far from being a mere process of typing. Composing a blog entry also involves research, planning and finally, execution. The research stage enables you to actively explore your interests, and interact with other people in the process. You can always join the community of already established bloggers and also talk with other people regarding their experiences in writing blogs about depression. ## Writing Can Improve Your Health As an activity which puts your memory, creativity, emotions and intellect to work together, writing is an excellent way to improve your health. Depression can harm the balance in your organism and cause other diseases. Writing for your blog gives you a chance to externalize your negative thoughts and feelings and deal with them with more objectivity. Some studies have discovered that writing about negative experiences for 20 minutes at a time for more than three days may result in lower blood pressure and a better and more effective immune system. ## Arouse Your Creativity There’s no doubt that writing can sometimes be very hard work, especially for people who don’t have previous experience with writing. Of course, being depressed does not improve the situation. However, once you get past your blockade, you will find that writing, although not easy, can be very rewarding. Writing eventually lets you discover and expand your creativity and thus gives you the chance to overcome one of the most harmful symptoms of depression – lethargy. ## Know Thyself The Ancient Greeks knew the importance of self-knowledge and self-discovery, and the aphorism ‘know thyself’ was inscribed on the door of the famous Temple of Apollo in Delphi. It’s been said that this was what the oracle said to people who came to seek knowledge about their future. [Getting to know yourself](http://expandedconsciousness.com/2016/04/13/ancient-methods-for-curing-depression/) is a powerful prerequisite of any treatment. This is where writing can help you connect with your inner being and helps you discover things about yourself you were previously unaware of. ## Sharing With Other People Sharing your thoughts, emotions and experiences with other people is arguably one of the best things about being a blogger. As we have said earlier, depression cannot be overcome without active help of other people, and the first step towards healing is when we acknowledge we have a problem. It’s important not to keep your negative emotions and experiences all to yourself. As soon as you gather the courage to act and talk about your problems, sooner the healing process can start. *About *author*: Samantha Brannon is an entrepreneur and freelancer. She is also a writing editor at [Trust Essays](http://www.trustessays.com/) and a contributing blogger for several websites. Samantha loves self-education and rock music. Connect with Samantha via [Twitter](https://twitter.com/SamantaBrannon)*
posts.html:
Battling depression is never easy and those who have experienced it firsthand know this much better than anyone else. Surprisingly, aside from the conventional methods of depression therapy available today, there are many more alternative techniques at one’s disposal when it comes to fighting depression.

For someone not acquainted with writing, and blog writing in particular, it may seem unusual – even outright impossible, that writing can be a mean to combat depression.

From this reason, our aim will be to show how writing your own personal blog can help you battle, and hopefully even overcome your depression.

You Are No Longer Alone

Depression is quite harder to handle when we are facing it alone. Here is where setting up your own blog helps you come out of your comfort zone into the wonderful world of online blogging. There are hundreds of thousands, perhaps even millions of people, who are blogging today and sharing their personal experiences to the public.

Your blog helps you share your experiences with others so that you are no longer alone.

Connect With Other People by Writing A Blog

Many people have, at some point, had issues with depression. Many of them also shared their experiences with others. There are many personal blogs today where people talk about their personal experiences at combating depression.

Creating your own blog gives you the opportunity to connect with people who have similar experiences and, more importantly, people who will understand and support you.

Express Yourself

A blog is your own internet diary. You should try and treat it just like you treat a handwritten personal diary. As we’ve said earlier, unlike a handwritten personal diary, a blog lets you connect with other people, but it is the process of expressing yourself through writing that is equally important. Sometimes, we cannot handle our emotions, experiences and memories and we lack the means to express them properly.

Writing is one of the best method of expressing yourself. Don’t be afraid to transfuse your thoughts into your blog.

Get Busy

They say idleness is a soul-killer. This is especially true for depression which cannot be successfully overcome in idleness and loneliness. If you don’t have a job, you can treat your blog as your primary occupation and devout your time to writing and improving it.

Giving yourself something to be preoccupied about is a great way of deflecting harmful thoughts. Consider setting up a daily schedule for posting new blog entries. Moreover, if you have audience following and commenting your blog posts, you will have a responsibility towards them.

You Have a Purpose

The lack of purpose is one of the leading causes behind depression. Finding motivation can be very hard, which is especially true if you have a job that does not fulfill you. A blog gives you a chance to do something you’re good at, and something that you genuinely care about.

Artistic Freedom

Anyone will tell you that the overwhelming feeling of freedom when writing is one of best things about being a writer.

Writing a blog is no different in this regard, and you will have complete freedom at deciding what to blog about.

Art therapy has been recognized as a proven method for combating depression. We have to emphasize that the quality of your writing is not of prime importance here. Even if it doesn’t look too good, this is not a reason to get worried or give up.

Your writing is your therapy and you are doing it to get in touch with your inner being. With time and practice your writing skills will also improve.

Explore Your Interests

Writing is far from being a mere process of typing. Composing a blog entry also involves research, planning and finally, execution. The research stage enables you to actively explore your interests, and interact with other people in the process.

You can always join the community of already established bloggers and also talk with other people regarding their experiences in writing blogs about depression.

Writing Can Improve Your Health

As an activity which puts your memory, creativity, emotions and intellect to work together, writing is an excellent way to improve your health. Depression can harm the balance in your organism and cause other diseases.

Writing for your blog gives you a chance to externalize your negative thoughts and feelings and deal with them with more objectivity.

Some studies have discovered that writing about negative experiences for 20 minutes at a time for more than three days may result in lower blood pressure and a better and more effective immune system.

Arouse Your Creativity

There’s no doubt that writing can sometimes be very hard work, especially for people who don’t have previous experience with writing. Of course, being depressed does not improve the situation. However, once you get past your blockade, you will find that writing, although not easy, can be very rewarding.

Writing eventually lets you discover and expand your creativity and thus gives you the chance to overcome one of the most harmful symptoms of depression – lethargy.

Know Thyself

The Ancient Greeks knew the importance of self-knowledge and self-discovery, and the aphorism ‘know thyself’ was inscribed on the door of the famous Temple of Apollo in Delphi. It’s been said that this was what the oracle said to people who came to seek knowledge about their future.

Getting to know yourself is a powerful prerequisite of any treatment. This is where writing can help you connect with your inner being and helps you discover things about yourself
you were previously unaware of.

Sharing With Other People

Sharing your thoughts, emotions and experiences with other people is arguably one of the best things about being a blogger. As we have said earlier, depression cannot be overcome without active help of other people, and the first step towards healing is when we acknowledge we have a problem.

It’s important not to keep your negative emotions and experiences all to yourself.

As soon as you gather the courage to act and talk about your problems, sooner the healing process can start.

About author: Samantha Brannon is an entrepreneur and freelancer. She is also a writing editor at Trust Essays and a contributing blogger for several websites. Samantha loves self-education and rock music. Connect with Samantha via Twitter

posts.title: 5 Good Reasons Elementary School Students Should NOT Be Given Homework
posts.markdown: For ages, homework has been a somewhat universally despised notion by kids across the globe. As if having to be in class all day wasn’t enough, extra work is being handed out to take home! Well, **[Harris Cooper](http://psychandneuro.duke.edu/people?Uil=cooperh&subpage=profile)**, author of *The Battle over Homework: Common Ground for Administrators, Teachers, and Parents*, and professor of Psychology and Neuroscience at Duke University, has been conducting research on homework for over 25 years. And he’s found some pretty interesting stuff. Homework, at the high school level, is actually seen to provide great benefit to students. However, this benefit becomes less and less as you move down the academic hierarchy. Middle school students do not benefit nearly as much, and elementary school students don’t benefit from homework at all. And others agree, like University of Arizona Education professor, **[Etta Kralovec](http://www.salon.com/2016/03/05/homework_is_wrecking_our_kids_the_research_is_clear_lets_ban_elementary_homework/)**. **Why homework should not be assigned to elementary school students** The research has pointed out a few reasons that homework should be done away with at the elementary school level: 1. Children at this level are just beginning their academic careers. Homework has been seen to have a negative impact on young students’ attitudes toward school, so making them dislike it from the start is counter-intuitive. Learning at this level should be fun and engaging. Having them read is noted as the better solution by researchers. 2. Homework is largely designed to build the relationship between parents and children, by having the parents get involved, but it has been seen to have the opposite effect on elementary school students. Because they need to be reminded about their homework at this age, kids and parents will often battle because doing more work before bedtime is not something they’re often interested in. This relationship can carry into later years of schooling where homework actually provides the most benefit. 3. Children gain a false sense of responsibility from homework. Many supporters of homework claim that regular homework gives children a sense of responsibility, but this has only been found to be true when they are older. Having to remind a child of homework every night destroys this sense of responsibility. 4. Homework takes up time that should be spent doing kid-stuff. Research has found that **[kids don’t exercise as much as they should](http://www.opencolleges.edu.au/informed/features/the-tyranny-of-homework-20-reasons-why-you-shouldnt-assign-homework-over-the-holidays/)**. Physical activities in the evenings and over the holidays, like team sports or just playing outside, benefit children much more than homework. 5. Rest is key to a child’s productivity in school. At this age, elementary school students should be getting about 10 hours of sleep per day, and homework often cuts into this time. If you want your child to be 100 percent ready to take on their day, they need that rest time.
posts.html:
For ages, homework has been a somewhat universally despised notion by kids across the globe. As if having to be in class all day wasn’t enough, extra work is being handed out to take home!

Well, Harris Cooper, author of The Battle over Homework: Common Ground for Administrators, Teachers, and Parents, and professor of Psychology and Neuroscience at Duke University, has been conducting research on homework for over 25 years. And he’s found some pretty interesting stuff.

Homework, at the high school level, is actually seen to provide great benefit to students. However, this benefit becomes less and less as you move down the academic hierarchy. Middle school students do not benefit nearly as much, and elementary school students don’t benefit from homework at all.

And others agree, like University of Arizona Education professor, Etta Kralovec.

Why homework should not be assigned to elementary school students

The research has pointed out a few reasons that homework should be done away with at the elementary school level:

  1. Children at this level are just beginning their academic careers. Homework has been seen to have a negative impact on young students’ attitudes toward school, so making them dislike it from the start is counter-intuitive. Learning at this level should be fun and engaging. Having them read is noted as the better solution by researchers.
  2. Homework is largely designed to build the relationship between parents and children, by having the parents get involved, but it has been seen to have the opposite effect on elementary school students. Because they need to be reminded about their homework at this age, kids and parents will often battle because doing more work before bedtime is not something they’re often interested in. This relationship can carry into later years of schooling where homework actually provides the most benefit.
  3. Children gain a false sense of responsibility from homework. Many supporters of homework claim that regular homework gives children a sense of responsibility, but this has only been found to be true when they are older. Having to remind a child of homework every night destroys this sense of responsibility.
  4. Homework takes up time that should be spent doing kid-stuff. Research has found that kids don’t exercise as much as they should. Physical activities in the evenings and over the holidays, like team sports or just playing outside, benefit children much more than homework.
  5. Rest is key to a child’s productivity in school. At this age, elementary school students should be getting about 10 hours of sleep per day, and homework often cuts into this time. If you want your child to be 100 percent ready to take on their day, they need that rest time.

posts.title: hcr-Men, Research Says That You Should Marry a Smart Woman If You Want to Live Longer
posts.markdown: Research Finds: Marrying a Smart Woman Makes a Man Live Longer Men Live Longer If They Marry Smart Women, Research Finds Men, when you go through the list of things you desire in a partner, does intelligence ever top your list? Attraction is of course multifaceted and complex, so all of us seek out different mates. But new research has found that intelligence might be the one thing we shouldn’t be ready to settle for, as [brainy partners](http://www.simplemost.com/marrying-smart-woman-help-prolong-life/) were found to extend lifespans and keep dementia at bay. [Professor Lawrence Whalley](http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3529167/Marry-intelligent-woman-defeat-dementia-men-told-Experts-say-brainy-partner-acts-buffer-disease.html), emeritus professor of mental health in the College of Medicine and Life Sciences at the University of Aberdeen, had this to say during a talk entitled ‘Dementia: How Can We Protect Ourselves?’ “‘The thing a boy is never told he needs to do if he wants to live a longer life – but what he should do – is marry an intelligent woman. There is no better buffer (to dementia) than intelligence.” The study, which comes out of the [University of Aberdeen](http://www.simplemost.com/marrying-smart-woman-help-prolong-life/), studied the health of identical twins and discovered that intelligent partners were a significant factor in how well a person was protected from degenerative brain diseases (like Alzheimer’s and dementia). It was found that men who partnered with intelligent women tended to live longer, happier lives, *and* had less risk of suffering from degenerative brain problems. This all stems from previous research showing that brain games, like [crossword puzzles](http://iheartintelligence.com/2016/04/25/benefits-crossword-puzzles/) for example, help stave off degenerative brain disease through stimulation of the brain. So, it would follow that a person whose brain is engaged and stimulated by their partner regularly would gain much of the same benefit. In fact, a small number of men who were married to intelligent partners *did *show signs of dementia during brain scans, but didn’t exhibit any of the symptoms, and were actually deemed “highly intelligent” and cognitively functional. Figuring out how to shift a cultural preference from beauty to intelligence is an endeavor we have yet to solve, however. It has been seen that [girls who grow up valuing their intelligence](http://everydayfeminism.com/2014/07/girls-taught-to-avoid-smart/) tend to be more independent, as well as empowered. Young boys who value intelligence have been seen to have stronger relationships with women and show far more support for their wives and daughters. Now, an argument can be made that choosing an intelligent wife is not only in your family’s best interest, but it is also beneficial to your overall well being and happiness! > [Men Who Marry Smart Women Live Longer](http://ideaspots.com/men-marry-smart-women-live-longer/)
posts.html:
Research Finds: Marrying a Smart Woman Makes a Man Live Longer

Men Live Longer If They Marry Smart Women, Research Finds

Men, when you go through the list of things you desire in a partner, does intelligence ever top your list? Attraction is of course multifaceted and complex, so all of us seek out different mates. But new research has found that intelligence might be the one thing we shouldn’t be ready to settle for, as brainy partners were found to extend lifespans and keep dementia at bay.

Professor Lawrence Whalley, emeritus professor of mental health in the College of Medicine and Life Sciences at the University of Aberdeen, had this to say during a talk entitled ‘Dementia: How Can We Protect Ourselves?’

“‘The thing a boy is never told he needs to do if he wants to live a longer life – but what he should do – is marry an intelligent woman. There is no better buffer (to dementia) than intelligence.”

The study, which comes out of the University of Aberdeen, studied the health of identical twins and discovered that intelligent partners were a significant factor in how well a person was protected from degenerative brain diseases (like Alzheimer’s and dementia).

It was found that men who partnered with intelligent women tended to live longer, happier lives, and had less risk of suffering from degenerative brain problems. This all stems from previous research showing that brain games, like crossword puzzles for example, help stave off degenerative brain disease through stimulation of the brain.

So, it would follow that a person whose brain is engaged and stimulated by their partner regularly would gain much of the same benefit. In fact, a small number of men who were married to intelligent partners did show signs of dementia during brain scans, but didn’t exhibit any of the symptoms, and were actually deemed “highly intelligent” and cognitively functional.

Figuring out how to shift a cultural preference from beauty to intelligence is an endeavor we have yet to solve, however.

It has been seen that girls who grow up valuing their intelligence tend to be more independent, as well as empowered. Young boys who value intelligence have been seen to have stronger relationships with women and show far more support for their wives and daughters.

Now, an argument can be made that choosing an intelligent wife is not only in your family’s best interest, but it is also beneficial to your overall well being and happiness!

Men Who Marry Smart Women Live Longer

posts.title: Stray Dog Helps Adopted Boy With Development Issues, The Results Are Beautiful
posts.markdown: A young boy named Danny would have his life changed in numerous ways after being adopted by Dixie and Edward, a loving couple who had already adopted two other children. Dixie knew that Danny would be coming home with them as soon as they saw his smile, even though doctors had told the couple that Danny was developing slower than he should be. Danny struggled in all of the areas a normal boy his age would be excelling at. From potty training to his speech abilities to his motor skills, everything was just a bit off. Edward and Dixie provided everything their kids could possibly need, but one thing was always out of the question: a dog. Fortunately, fate had other plans. Dennie, a woman who lived next door to Edward and Dixie, trained search canines. At the time, Dennie was training a young dog named Saki. Saki was almost finished with her training when she started behaving strangely. Almost every day, Saki tried to figure out how to escape the backyard. Until one day, she finally made it out. Where did she go? Straight across the street to meet Danny. From that day forth, Saki would make her way out of the backyard and over to Danny, as if she knew the young boy had needed her for a long time. Remarkably, Danny started to change after Saki came into his life. Not only did he speak his first ever proper and complete sentence (“I am Saki’s daddy”), but he became potty trained and even began throwing balls. Saki’s training eventually finished, however, and she was set to leave for the rescue organization. Dixie, recognizing the importance of this dog for her son, told Dennie to ask the organization if they could keep her. The organization refused until Dennie told them to come and witness just how precious Saki and Danny’s relationship was. They did, and it was decided. Saki and Danny would not be separated. *Don’t forget to share with friends and family who would be touched by Danny’s story!*
posts.html:
A young boy named Danny would have his life changed in numerous ways after being adopted by Dixie and Edward, a loving couple who had already adopted two other children.

Dixie knew that Danny would be coming home with them as soon as they saw his smile, even though doctors had told the couple that Danny was developing slower than he should be. Danny struggled in all of the areas a normal boy his age would be excelling at. From potty training to his speech abilities to his motor skills, everything was just a bit off.

Edward and Dixie provided everything their kids could possibly need, but one thing was always out of the question: a dog.

Fortunately, fate had other plans.

Dennie, a woman who lived next door to Edward and Dixie, trained search canines. At the time, Dennie was training a young dog named Saki. Saki was almost finished with her training when she started behaving strangely. Almost every day, Saki tried to figure out how to escape the backyard.

Until one day, she finally made it out. Where did she go? Straight across the street to meet Danny. From that day forth, Saki would make her way out of the backyard and over to Danny, as if she knew the young boy had needed her for a long time.

Remarkably, Danny started to change after Saki came into his life. Not only did he speak his first ever proper and complete sentence (“I am Saki’s daddy”), but he became potty trained and even began throwing balls.

Saki’s training eventually finished, however, and she was set to leave for the rescue organization. Dixie, recognizing the importance of this dog for her son, told Dennie to ask the organization if they could keep her. The organization refused until Dennie told them to come and witness just how precious Saki and Danny’s relationship was.

They did, and it was decided. Saki and Danny would not be separated.

Don’t forget to share with friends and family who would be touched by Danny’s story!

posts.title: hcr-This Powerful Ad About Abandoned Children Has a Twist Ending
posts.markdown: This Powerful Ad for Abandoned Children Has a Shocking End While the video below portrays a fictitious story, tales like this one are common all over the world. A married couple makes the decision to build their family a little bigger by adopting a little girl. At first, things were going exactly as planned. The little girl they had adopted was getting along famously with her new sister and the family was happy. But as time went on, the young girl’s place in the family came into question. She started making little mistakes at home, and began whining for attention and love. After one particularly bad mess she made, the family starts to think that maybe they made the wrong decision to adopt her. She’s not behaving like a normal child, even though they know that she has had an unfortunate past. So, the family decides that this little girl has to go. The dad takes her to a field in the middle of nowhere and leaves her there, by herself. But as he’s driving away, he sees the little girl in his rear-view mirror, and what happens next is absolutely shocking. Watch and experience this powerful video that challenges you to think about innocent beings who are abandoned every day. *And don’t forget to share with friends and family who you think would also be moved by this story*   http://www.littlethings.com/the-gift-of-abandonment/

posts.title: 5 Things About Nikola Tesla That Most People Don’t Know
posts.markdown: Nikola Tesla, the beloved inventor, engineer, and physicist, had his birthday just a couple weeks ago on July 10th, which makes him 160 years old! Tesla is revered around the world for his contributions to modern society, including the alternating current electricity system, which is used by most residential homes and commercial business spaces today. Tesla passed away in 1943, but his reputation as an eccentric, genius of a man continues to inspire and influence generation after generation of freethinkers. To celebrate his birthday, here are five facts about this brilliant man you may not have known! **He was an avid environmentalist** Tesla knew that the people of Earth would eventually start to drain the planet of its natural resources, so renewable energy sources were something he was very interested in. His research focused largely on finding methods to harness natural energy from the earth and the sky, hoping to limit fossil fuel consumption. **Tesla was actually born during a lightning storm** Like something straight out of a fairy tale, Nikola Tesla, the master of electricity, was in fact born during a particularly powerful lightning storm. The midwife helping deliver Nikola from his mother saw this event as a bad omen, claiming Nikola would be a “child of darkness.” His mother promptly told the midwife, “No, he will be a child of light.” And so he was. **He was a humanist at heart** Tesla’s humanist ideology was a strong motivator for him to develop things that would benefit his fellow man. He was largely interested in bettering the quality of human life, but not for personal gain. Which is why he died poor, even though his inventions and ideas contributed greatly to the progress of mankind. **Tesla predicted wireless internet. In 1901.** Tesla’s capacity for imagining the future was incredible. During his development of the transatlantic radio, he pictured a massive system of information that could be encoded and broadcasted to hand-held devices. Which is exactly how the world unfolded, over a 100 years after his death. Other early visions of his that would eventually turn into reality include radar technology, X-ray technology, a ‘death ray’ particle cannon, and certain pieces of radio astronomy technology. **He had an immaculate memory** Tesla’s memory capacity was nothing short of astonishing. After being only briefly exposed to books or images, Tesla could recall vivid and highly specific details about them, sometimes even being able to remember entire books. Allegedly, Tesla used his incredible imagination to diffuse the intense nightmares that plagued him as a child.

Nikola Tesla, the beloved inventor, engineer, and physicist, had his birthday just a couple weeks ago on July 10th, which makes him 160 years old! Tesla is revered around the world for his contributions to modern society, including the alternating current electricity system, which is used by most residential homes and commercial business spaces today.

Tesla passed away in 1943, but his reputation as an eccentric, genius of a man continues to inspire and influence generation after generation of freethinkers.

To celebrate his birthday, here are five facts about this brilliant man you may not have known!

He was an avid environmentalist

Tesla knew that the people of Earth would eventually start to drain the planet of its natural resources, so renewable energy sources were something he was very interested in. His research focused largely on finding methods to harness natural energy from the earth and the sky, hoping to limit fossil fuel consumption.

Tesla was actually born during a lightning storm

Like something straight out of a fairy tale, Nikola Tesla, the master of electricity, was in fact born during a particularly powerful lightning storm. The midwife helping deliver Nikola from his mother saw this event as a bad omen, claiming Nikola would be a “child of darkness.”

His mother promptly told the midwife, “No, he will be a child of light.” And so he was.

He was a humanist at heart

Tesla’s humanist ideology was a strong motivator for him to develop things that would benefit his fellow man. He was largely interested in bettering the quality of human life, but not for personal gain. Which is why he died poor, even though his inventions and ideas contributed greatly to the progress of mankind.

Tesla predicted wireless internet. In 1901.

Tesla’s capacity for imagining the future was incredible. During his development of the transatlantic radio, he pictured a massive system of information that could be encoded and broadcasted to hand-held devices. Which is exactly how the world unfolded, over a 100 years after his death.

Other early visions of his that would eventually turn into reality include radar technology, X-ray technology, a ‘death ray’ particle cannon, and certain pieces of radio astronomy technology.

He had an immaculate memory

Tesla’s memory capacity was nothing short of astonishing. After being only briefly exposed to books or images, Tesla could recall vivid and highly specific details about them, sometimes even being able to remember entire books. Allegedly, Tesla used his incredible imagination to diffuse the intense nightmares that plagued him as a child.

posts.title: hcr-Owner of Dog With Terminal Cancer Takes His Pup On One Last Adventure
posts.markdown: Owner of Dog With Terminal Cancer Takes His Pup On One Last Adventure Man Takes His Dying Dog On One Last Adventure ![ ](http://i2.cdn.turner.com/cnnnext/dam/assets/160713132442-bella-lake-erie-exlarge-169.jpg) “Man’s best friend” has been the phrase used to describe our canine companions for as long as we can remember, and with good reason.  Dogs make some of the best pets and most owners come to see them as their children or members of the family.   Thus, one of the saddest parts of dog ownership is knowing that you will likely outlive your best friend, a possibility that turned into reality for Robert Kugler.   Kugler’s best friend was a chocolate labrador named Bella, and she was diagnosed with bone cancer in her leg. After her leg was amputated, Kugler hoped that would be the end of it, but the cancer had actually spread to Bella’s lungs and was now terminal. ![ ](http://i2.cdn.turner.com/cnnnext/dam/assets/160713132208-bella-cleveland-exlarge-169.jpg) “This is one of the biggest connections I’ve ever had to another living being. I don’t care that it’s a dog,” said Kugler. Kugler has been with his pup since adopting her about nine years ago, so finding out that she might not around for much longer was devastating. “I just didn’t want her to be gone one day when I came home,” he said. So, Kugler decided that he and Bella needed to take one last adventure together, their biggest one yet.  Starting out at the Marine Corps. Ball in Chicago (because Kugler is a Marine veteran), Bella and Kugler travelled to random locations around the region.   ![ ](http://i2.cdn.turner.com/cnnnext/dam/assets/160713132656-belle-niagara-falls-exlarge-169.jpg) ![ ](http://i2.cdn.turner.com/cnnnext/dam/assets/160713133115-bella-fenway-park-exlarge-169.jpg) ![ ](http://i2.cdn.turner.com/cnnnext/dam/assets/160713133331-bella-lincoln-memorial-exlarge-169.jpg) From the Niagra Falls to Fenway Park to the Lincoln Memorial, Kugler and Bella camped out of the car or couchsurfed with friends as they made their way to each new destination.   “I want to inspire people to get outside and live,” Kugler said. “Love each other for who we are and make friends.” While Bella has survived for longer than doctors had anticipated, Kugler recognizes that her time is limited. “Some days I’m completely prepared. I pictured her just swimming out to sea,” “But there’s other days when I’m like, oh my God, I can’t bear the thought of it.” “We take on these animals, which means we’re gonna take on their life and their passing,” Kugler said. “To be there with them when they pass is the greatest gift you can give anybody.” After Bella has passed, Kugler says he’ll likely try to spend more time volunteering with organizations like [Team Rubicon](http://www.teamrubiconusa.org/) and [Team Red, White & Blue](https://www.teamrwb.org/), both of which focus on helping veterans. In the meantime, Kugler hopes that everyone can be inspired by Bella’s story to “Wag more [and] bark less.” *You can keep following Kugler and Bella on social media: * *[Twitter](https://twitter.com/robkugler) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/robert.kugler1) | [Instragram](https://www.instagram.com/robkugler/)* http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/13/health/dog-last-trip-trnd/index.html
posts.html:
Owner of Dog With Terminal Cancer Takes His Pup On One Last Adventure

Man Takes His Dying Dog On One Last Adventure

“Man’s best friend” has been the phrase used to describe our canine companions for as long as we can remember, and with good reason.  Dogs make some of the best pets and most owners come to see them as their children or members of the family.  

Thus, one of the saddest parts of dog ownership is knowing that you will likely outlive your best friend, a possibility that turned into reality for Robert Kugler.  

Kugler’s best friend was a chocolate labrador named Bella, and she was diagnosed with bone cancer in her leg. After her leg was amputated, Kugler hoped that would be the end of it, but the cancer had actually spread to Bella’s lungs and was now terminal.

“This is one of the biggest connections I’ve ever had to another living being. I don’t care that it’s a dog,” said Kugler.

Kugler has been with his pup since adopting her about nine years ago, so finding out that she might not around for much longer was devastating.

“I just didn’t want her to be gone one day when I came home,” he said.

So, Kugler decided that he and Bella needed to take one last adventure together, their biggest one yet.  Starting out at the Marine Corps. Ball in Chicago (because Kugler is a Marine veteran), Bella and Kugler travelled to random locations around the region.  

From the Niagra Falls to Fenway Park to the Lincoln Memorial, Kugler and Bella camped out of the car or couchsurfed with friends as they made their way to each new destination.  

“I want to inspire people to get outside and live,” Kugler said. “Love each other for who we are and make friends.”

While Bella has survived for longer than doctors had anticipated, Kugler recognizes that her time is limited.

“Some days I’m completely prepared. I pictured her just swimming out to sea,”

“But there’s other days when I’m like, oh my God, I can’t bear the thought of it.”

“We take on these animals, which means we’re gonna take on their life and their passing,” Kugler said. “To be there with them when they pass is the greatest gift you can give anybody.”

After Bella has passed, Kugler says he’ll likely try to spend more time volunteering with organizations like Team Rubicon and Team Red, White & Blue, both of which focus on helping veterans.

In the meantime, Kugler hopes that everyone can be inspired by Bella’s story to “Wag more [and] bark less.”

You can keep following Kugler and Bella on social media:

Twitter | Facebook | Instragram

http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/13/health/dog-last-trip-trnd/index.html

posts.title: 6 Rejuvenating Yoga Poses You Can Do in Your Bed
posts.markdown: *All photo credit goes to [Sophie Jaffe](http://www.thephilosophie.com/) | Follow her on [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/philosophiemama/), [Twitter](https://twitter.com/philosophiemama) and [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/philosophiemama/) * Maybe you’re a person who likes to get up and do yoga in the morning, or maybe you’re like me and prefer to do a few postures before bedtime.  Either way, doing yoga in bed is fun, relaxing, and it sets the pace for a peaceful, and grounded, next few hours. Additonally, if it’s difficult to wake up and get going with your yoga routine first thing in the morning, try helpful tools like the Yoga Wake up app.  This helpful tool wakes you up with a soft, audio-based yoga sequence conducted by teachers like Jen Smith and Derek Beres. Ease into a peaceful night of rest or jump start your day with these six yoga poses that can be done in bed: **Child Pose, Wide-Legged (Balasana)** ![Wide-Legged Child Pose or Balasana](http://img.aws.livestrongcdn.com/ls-article-image-640/cme/photography.prod.demandstudios.com/9552e2d0-1ab5-4658-82cc-bfa3834f6337.jpg) Kneeling on your bed, begin by lowering your rear down between your feet, spreading your legs wide as you lower your body.  Next, fully extend the torso and both arms forward as your forehead lies on the bed.  Sink down into the pose and feel the stretching in your back, legs and arms.   Hold this posture for 30 seconds to a minute, with normal breathing as you do so. **The Seated Forward Fold (Paschimottanasana)** ![Seated Forward Fold or Paschimottanasana](http://img.aws.livestrongcdn.com/ls-article-image-640/cme/photography.prod.demandstudios.com/1a8f8e11-e5ca-4d4a-bc89-081bc5f8fab4.jpg) Starting seated, bring your legs together in front of your body and feel the flexing of your feet.  Bring your arms up and then extend forward with a straight back, reaching for your ankles or the bottoms of your feet.  Be sure to keep breathing as you focus on relaxed shoulders and a straight back.   Hold this posture for 30 seconds to a minute. **Supine Spine Twist (Supta Matsyendrasana)** ![Supine Spinal Twist or Supta Matsyendrasana](http://img.aws.livestrongcdn.com/ls-article-image-640/cme/photography.prod.demandstudios.com/8b46a0c9-8ad9-4e1e-86fd-4d81a574db67.jpg) Begin by lying down on your back.  Slowly bring your right knee up and close to your chest, and then gently twist and let it drop to the left side of the body.  With your left hand on your right leg, bring your right arm (and your focus) out to the right.  Feel the stretching in your spine, back and legs.   Hold this posture for five to ten breaths for each side of the body. **Fish Pose (Matsyasana)** ![Fish pose or Matsyasana](http://img.aws.livestrongcdn.com/ls-article-image-640/cme/photography.prod.demandstudios.com/289aa59e-5f6d-4061-ab85-6065fae5e16e.jpg) Begin this posture by lying on your back, legs together and arms at your sides.  Then, as you exhale, bend at the elbows, pushing the elbows inward as you lift the palms of your hands upward, lifting your chest into the air.  Let the crown of your head fall back and touch whatever surface you’re on. Keep your legs engaged, and squeeze the shoulder blades with every exhale. Remember to breathe, and hold this pose for 30 seconds. **The Happy Baby Posture (Ananda Balasana)** ![Happy Baby Pose or Ananda Balasana](http://img.aws.livestrongcdn.com/ls-article-image-640/cme/photography.prod.demandstudios.com/cd6248c1-0f29-42ea-a0f5-b98ac00d83cf.jpg) Just like a newborn would, lie on your back, bring your knees to your chest and then reach down and grab and hold the outside edges of your feet.  Let your hips relax, helping your lower back to rest comfortably on the bed.  Focus on bringing your ankles over your knees, as well as touching your tailbone to the bed.   Be sure to breathe as you hold this posture for at least one minute. **Seated Pose (Sukasana)** ![Seated Pose or Sukasana](http://img.aws.livestrongcdn.com/ls-article-image-640/cme/photography.prod.demandstudios.com/41b4c04d-4069-40ab-ad51-5a4fd76152e7.jpg) This somewhat basic pose provides great benefits.  Sit down on your rear in a traditional cross-legged seated posture with your feet relaxed.  Focus on bringing your spine into a straight alignment as you sit up.  With palms facing down, bring your hands to rest on your knees, or bring them together at the center of your chest.   Focus on your breathing as you create an absolute awareness of the peace and serenity you are experiencing in the moment. *All photo credit goes to [Sophie Jaffe](http://www.thephilosophie.com/) | Follow her on [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/philosophiemama/), [Twitter](https://twitter.com/philosophiemama) and [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/philosophiemama/) * h/t [**LiveStrong**](http://www.livestrong.com/article/1011650-8-energizing-yoga-moves-can-bed/)
posts.html:
All photo credit goes to Sophie Jaffe | Follow her on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram

Maybe you’re a person who likes to get up and do yoga in the morning, or maybe you’re like me and prefer to do a few postures before bedtime.  Either way, doing yoga in bed is fun, relaxing, and it sets the pace for a peaceful, and grounded, next few hours.

Additonally, if it’s difficult to wake up and get going with your yoga routine first thing in the morning, try helpful tools like the Yoga Wake up app.  This helpful tool wakes you up with a soft, audio-based yoga sequence conducted by teachers like Jen Smith and Derek Beres.

Ease into a peaceful night of rest or jump start your day with these six yoga poses that can be done in bed:

Child Pose, Wide-Legged (Balasana)

Kneeling on your bed, begin by lowering your rear down between your feet, spreading your legs wide as you lower your body.  Next, fully extend the torso and both arms forward as your forehead lies on the bed.  Sink down into the pose and feel the stretching in your back, legs and arms.  

Hold this posture for 30 seconds to a minute, with normal breathing as you do so.

The Seated Forward Fold (Paschimottanasana)

Starting seated, bring your legs together in front of your body and feel the flexing of your feet.  Bring your arms up and then extend forward with a straight back, reaching for your ankles or the bottoms of your feet.  Be sure to keep breathing as you focus on relaxed shoulders and a straight back.  

Hold this posture for 30 seconds to a minute.

Supine Spine Twist (Supta Matsyendrasana)

Begin by lying down on your back.  Slowly bring your right knee up and close to your chest, and then gently twist and let it drop to the left side of the body.  With your left hand on your right leg, bring your right arm (and your focus) out to the right.  Feel the stretching in your spine, back and legs.  

Hold this posture for five to ten breaths for each side of the body.

Fish Pose (Matsyasana)

Begin this posture by lying on your back, legs together and arms at your sides.  Then, as you exhale, bend at the elbows, pushing the elbows inward as you lift the palms of your hands upward, lifting your chest into the air.  Let the crown of your head fall back and touch whatever surface you’re on. Keep your legs engaged, and squeeze the shoulder blades with every exhale.

Remember to breathe, and hold this pose for 30 seconds.

The Happy Baby Posture (Ananda Balasana)

Just like a newborn would, lie on your back, bring your knees to your chest and then reach down and grab and hold the outside edges of your feet.  Let your hips relax, helping your lower back to rest comfortably on the bed.  Focus on bringing your ankles over your knees, as well as touching your tailbone to the bed.  

Be sure to breathe as you hold this posture for at least one minute.

Seated Pose (Sukasana)

This somewhat basic pose provides great benefits.  Sit down on your rear in a traditional cross-legged seated posture with your feet relaxed.  Focus on bringing your spine into a straight alignment as you sit up.  With palms facing down, bring your hands to rest on your knees, or bring them together at the center of your chest.  

Focus on your breathing as you create an absolute awareness of the peace and serenity you are experiencing in the moment.

All photo credit goes to Sophie Jaffe | Follow her on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram

h/t LiveStrong

posts.title: Shortly Before Passing Away, Sam Told the World His Three Secrets to Happiness
posts.markdown: Diagnosed with a rare disease called ‘progeria,’ 17-year-old Sam Berns lead anything but a normal life.  Three months before his passing, he gave an inspiring and powerful speech illustrating his struggles to overcome the obstacles he faced every day, as well as his methods to finally beat them. Progeria, the extremely rare disease that Sam suffered from, causes rapid aging and a slew of other debilitating symptoms.  But Sam never gave up on living a happy life, and he wants you to remember that you are capable of doing the same. Sam’s TEDx video is just one thing he did to try to create a better world for the people around him.  You can learn more about Sam by watching his HBO documentary, and you can learn more about Progeria at the Progeria Research Foundation.

posts.title: 3 Important Life Lessons Everyone Can Learn From Being Single
posts.markdown: If you’ve recently found yourself single or have been single for a while, I have some good news: you’re growing.  Being single affords you many opportunities and freedoms that people in relationships do not have.  Think about it–no one to answer to, no one else to worry about but yourself, no trying to figure out someone else’s life. A large importance is placed on relationships because, well, that’s kind of our purpose as humans; we’re meant to get together and make babies.  But that doesn’t mean you need to be in a relationship *all the time*.   Being single actually helps us learn a few important life lessons.  They can be rough lessons to learn, but you’re better off for having learned them! **Spending time alone** Sometimes when we have a partner, we get used to certain comforts and develop dependencies around them.  Sometimes we even stop doing the things that make us, us.  When you spend time alone, you remember all the things you used to spend your time doing; you know, the hobbies and activities that you call your own. Being alone also gives you the downtime necessary to reflect on the happenings of your life.  You can think about past mistakes and grow from them. **You are more than enough for yourself** One of the best things about learning to live comfortably alone is that you don’t seek out validation from anyone other than yourself.  If you gain nothing else from being alone, try to learn this.  Once you start to live life for yourself, numerous doors open up in your world, each one brimming with potential.   Because the truth is that you are the only one who knows what will make you happy.  And only you can decide what is best for you.  Remember to do right by yourself before anyone else. **Love can be found in all parts of life, not just your relationships** When you’re single, you start to discover love in different areas of your life.  You start to develop an understanding of love that is greater and much deeper than before.  This helps you to love unconditionally at all times, regardless of what is going on or who you’re with.  And in turn, you become a better version of yourself. Being single is not something to be feared or looked down upon.  It is an opportunity for growth, an opportunity to truly learn about yourself.  Remember that you are the only person you need in this world and move forward with confidence every day!
posts.html:
If you’ve recently found yourself single or have been single for a while, I have some good news: you’re growing.  Being single affords you many opportunities and freedoms that people in relationships do not have.  Think about it–no one to answer to, no one else to worry about but yourself, no trying to figure out someone else’s life.

A large importance is placed on relationships because, well, that’s kind of our purpose as humans; we’re meant to get together and make babies.  But that doesn’t mean you need to be in a relationship all the time.  

Being single actually helps us learn a few important life lessons.  They can be rough lessons to learn, but you’re better off for having learned them!

Spending time alone

Sometimes when we have a partner, we get used to certain comforts and develop dependencies around them.  Sometimes we even stop doing the things that make us, us.  When you spend time alone, you remember all the things you used to spend your time doing; you know, the hobbies and activities that you call your own.

Being alone also gives you the downtime necessary to reflect on the happenings of your life.  You can think about past mistakes and grow from them.

You are more than enough for yourself

One of the best things about learning to live comfortably alone is that you don’t seek out validation from anyone other than yourself.  If you gain nothing else from being alone, try to learn this.  Once you start to live life for yourself, numerous doors open up in your world, each one brimming with potential.  

Because the truth is that you are the only one who knows what will make you happy.  And only you can decide what is best for you.  Remember to do right by yourself before anyone else.

Love can be found in all parts of life, not just your relationships

When you’re single, you start to discover love in different areas of your life.  You start to develop an understanding of love that is greater and much deeper than before.  This helps you to love unconditionally at all times, regardless of what is going on or who you’re with.  And in turn, you become a better version of yourself.

Being single is not something to be feared or looked down upon.  It is an opportunity for growth, an opportunity to truly learn about yourself.  Remember that you are the only person you need in this world and move forward with confidence every day!

posts.title: This Man Comforts a Gorilla After Its Mom Was Killed by Poachers
posts.markdown: Losing a loved one is always a tragic process, and it’s an experience that is not unique to humans.  Among animals we’ve seen to practice mourning of their fallen family or herd members are elephants, giraffes, and gorillas, to name a few.  And**[Phil Moore](http://philmoore.info/)**’s photograph above illustrates this sentiment. This young mountain gorilla, who’s resting on a fallen log with a man, just **[lost his mother to poachers](http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2014/06/140627-congo-virunga-wildlife-rangers-elephants-rhinos-poaching/)**, a pain that is understood across species.  You can see the gorilla grasping park ranger Patrick Karabaranga’s leg, as the man places one arm around the gorilla and one hand on top of his. This photo was taken in **[July of 2012](http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2014/06/140627-congo-virunga-wildlife-rangers-elephants-rhinos-poaching/)** at the **[Virunga National Park](http://visitvirunga.org/about-virunga/)**, located in the Democratic Republic of Congo, and perfectly captures the very real pain that is understood by numerous forms of life. ![](https://scontent-yyz1-1.xx.fbcdn.net/v/t1.0-0/s552x414/10568929_10152618451360782_4527039419934660534_n.jpg?oh=256964871f8c2ef82e7d9014d35cfe0f&oe=582FF197) Even though Karabaranga shows us that humans are capable of showing compassion for individuals of other species, mountain gorillas are in fact endangered.  And they’re endangered because of *us*.   ![](https://scontent-yyz1-1.xx.fbcdn.net/v/t1.0-0/s552x414/10426649_10152418308845782_5529096300959615977_n.jpg?oh=a673293955291f94fe429eed96a2ae5f&oe=582CC31B) Mass deforestation has destroyed many of the habitats mountain gorillas and other species used to call home.  [About 80,000 acres](http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/earth-talks-daily-destruction/) of rainforest are consumed every day by industries such as [logging, agriculture and mining](http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/earth-talks-daily-destruction/). On top of that, these operations have lead to the arrival of [poachers](http://video.nationalgeographic.com/video/gorilla_lowland_poaching) in the area, who use the new roads and transportation methods to reach gorilla habitats, as well as to ship out their meat. ![](https://scontent-yyz1-1.xx.fbcdn.net/v/t1.0-0/s552x414/307385_10150298799335782_1099769_n.jpg?oh=16de6cb12f6017e7e5671625f3249e8f&oe=5831522F) There are [conservation efforts](http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/sep/11/mountain-gorillas-conservation) being put forth to help restore the gorilla population, but as the heartbreaking photo above tells us, their work is nowhere close to being done. https://www.thedodo.com/gorilla-seeks-comfort-1355648291.html
posts.html:
Losing a loved one is always a tragic process, and it’s an experience that is not unique to humans.  Among animals we’ve seen to practice mourning of their fallen family or herd members are elephants, giraffes, and gorillas, to name a few.  And Phil Moore’s photograph above illustrates this sentiment.

This young mountain gorilla, who’s resting on a fallen log with a man, just lost his mother to poachers, a pain that is understood across species.  You can see the gorilla grasping park ranger Patrick Karabaranga’s leg, as the man places one arm around the gorilla and one hand on top of his.

This photo was taken in July of 2012 at the Virunga National Park, located in the Democratic Republic of Congo, and perfectly captures the very real pain that is understood by numerous forms of life.

Even though Karabaranga shows us that humans are capable of showing compassion for individuals of other species, mountain gorillas are in fact endangered.  And they’re endangered because of us.  

Mass deforestation has destroyed many of the habitats mountain gorillas and other species used to call home.  About 80,000 acres of rainforest are consumed every day by industries such as logging, agriculture and mining.

On top of that, these operations have lead to the arrival of poachers in the area, who use the new roads and transportation methods to reach gorilla habitats, as well as to ship out their meat.

There are conservation efforts being put forth to help restore the gorilla population, but as the heartbreaking photo above tells us, their work is nowhere close to being done.

https://www.thedodo.com/gorilla-seeks-comfort-1355648291.html

posts.title: An Ontological Manifesto
posts.markdown:
There has been a strong inflation in the number of militant atheists pompously wagging fingers at the religious. ‘Faith is clearly not true, for it’s neither rational nor empirical in nature.’ Faith consists of a Truth that cannot be justified on an objective scale from one’s own subjectivity, and therefore any belief derived from an irreproducible means is undoubtedly false to the atheist. The thing that cannot be tested is not accepted; this is an atheist’s mindset. Additionally, atheists have the rationalized brain type to nimbly forgo the abstraction and metaphor many holy texts employ. I am not a foot-peddler for religion, but the obstinate narcissists of atheism must quiet.

Language is a means for information transfer. It is not the only way, nor is it omnipotent in its ability. Often, abstraction is needed to transfer immense concepts to others, in ways no other communicational technique can. The return of Christ is impossible, for he has died. And this is true, a physical rebirth is impossible – biology knows this. Though if the death was looked at as a degree of consciousness, this seems more public and reproducible of a substrate to maintain truth. If the second coming of Jesus were at a level of consciousness, the statement stands.

Causality isn’t my God. For if He were, He’d have competition. Synchronicity exists by His side, as Jung has conjectured: A field of instantaneous connection based on meaning, which works concurrently with physical spacetime. This is the science of consciousness, i.e. the science of the next 50 years. We don’t understand consciousness; we only understand space, time, and our material reality. Yet the thing which makes it all possible [consciousness] is either faced with apathy, neglectful ignorance, or fear. We know one of the two must be true: There is a physical process causing consciousness happenings, or there is a preexisting consciousness that organizes matter. The atheist will not consider the latter. Perhaps consciousness — its direction and its degree — affects radioactive break up and electron collapse. Perhaps pushing our consciousness into an imaginary space where a future physical reality is envisaged mimics the actual experience in regard to brain activity and increases the probability that such a future will unfold. This can be looked at as a path of least resistance, while keeping intention (strength and direction) of consciousness considered. If we want to trigger an action potential in a neuron, Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS) can work analogously to bring the neuron closer to a depolarized state, where it is facilitated in the birth of a firing signal, leading to an entire cascade of new probabilistic realities. As David Deutsche has stated:

> “If you are an artist and halfway through creating a work of art you see something in it that you want to bring out, then you are being attracted by a beauty that you have not yet experienced.”

 The projection of consciousness to a future reality that meets an attraction within the individual will push his action there. An internal idea he passionately rips into an external state.

We again crash into this duality of internal and external world, but the rationalist only takes what he can see. Unfortunately, if to see is to understand… vision is dismal. One cannot understand the driving force and the internal calculations behind the artist’s piece; one cannot pack up his belongings and move into the artist’s mind. This is to say that one cannot mimic another’s conscious state or peer into another’s subjectivity.  
 Consciousness has eluded man for as long as we know. This is because once man is elucidated to his own consciousness, he is no longer man; he leaves the search. When a consciousness receives such a degree of resonate truth that it knows with all of its being that an answer is correct: this needs no secondary explanation, nor should it. It is at this point where the consciousness realizes the profound clarity that comes with the dismissal of a veil. A flash of insight can be used as comparison here. The high altitude burst of gamma frequency oscillation emitted when an individual gets access to such a degree of gamma state consciousness is when the highest degree of truth he has had in quite some time is elucidated. (Sheth, B. R., Sandkühler, S., & Bhattacharya, J. (2009).) *Posterior beta and anterior gamma oscillations predict cognitive insight*. So much so, it may actually be perceptible in an excited physiological state of the insula, right PFC, and anterior cingulate. A subsequent positive emotion generally follows suit too. Though one man may have a flash of insight into the nature of an external issue, another man may of *himself*. The man of internal insight has found a truth that resonates with a subjective piece of the universe; a phenomenon deafened to the atheist. Tell me how you expect such a resonance to be of any value to – never mind represented in – a different entity, with different strings. Such a resonance wouldn’t be consonant with a machine of a different assemblage. Understanding consists of a *need* to create an empathetic acceptance, a knowing of truth by an inter/intra-personal mental resonance.  
 It is natural that ignorance can cause a man to accept a false truth, which may aggregate into a foundation of ‘understanding,’ conflicting with our own. In argument this is the underlying battle, to move his truth in accordance with mine, without moving mine to his. One can also see that ego is the construct, unyielding and persistent. It is this persistence which forces a larger/more intelligent ego to compound his truth onto another’s, disregarding some of them along the way.

As John Lennox has pointed out, an atheist who stumbles upon a car engine can tell you exactly how the car engine works. The point is though, he cannot not give you an explanation of how it got there. This question is just as valid, but the atheist dismisses it. The two outlooks are as follows: It’s beyond empiricism to him and thus *unprovable*, or moreover, that the way in which the engine works *brought* it there. The rationalist asks ‘what’s going on,’ while those of faith prefer ‘who’s asking the question?’ In this competition for truth, the logic-minded look externally, while the religious look within. Thus we should not idolize logic, for it is inherently limited, and sometimes the alogical is true. Furthermore, Gödel’s theorem shows us that some truths are unprovable. Yet the limited intelligibility of the rationalist’s mind purports his foundation of logic as absolute, with every tenet axiomatic in nature.

Humans are hardwired to think linearly – it’s how we measure time. So for the rationalist, the caste we’re born into has no ultimate explanation, nor does an existence proceeding death. To look before the start is illogical for a linear mind. He didn’t choose where he grew up, he didn’t choose his parents, yet he’s born and it’s game on – ‘from here forward is what I’ll ‘consider,’ he says. One who looks at time cyclically finds sense in the ideas of heaven and hell, death and rebirth. Still the problem runs deeper. It is the rationalist’s incognizant fear of the unconscious mind that impedes the self-knowledge the spiritual knows and loves. To say you understand the unconscious mind is to flatly lie. We can either muster an implicit comprehension or claim it incomprehensible altogether. Though as Jung has observed, the unconscious is the only available source of spiritual experience. It is the medium from which religious experiences seem to flow. Coincidentally, *Flow* is also the coined term for the experience by which one meshes his consciousness with the environment, where egocentric individuality dissipates altogether. In this state there is no self-critic, and the unconscious mind drives behavior as we become immersed in our favorite activities. In these states we see performance is optimal, creativity is heightened, and intuition is bountiful.

**Ego**

To provide another analogy, we can look at the ego as a neuron. We have an adequate understanding of how the neuron fires mechanically but no confident way of knowing how the cascade of other summated signals – that is the unconscious – triggered that neuron with such temporal precision. As Freud explained, there is a ‘fringe of consciousness,’ with only the most salient information entering. It should be understood that it is the summation of subthreshold information – of which we are not aware – that creates the wave into conscious awareness.  
 For a moment, consider the question: What founds thought? We may consciously try to move thought in our desired direction, but what is that ruminating voice that pops into our inner dialogue throughout the day? Why are the contents sometimes even shunned by the conscious mind? This should not be the case for a consciously driven thought process. Think about a conversation or my writing this sentence. I don’t have a preexisting, consciously planned out script from which I’m typing. The content of my unconscious mind is being translated to conscious information in the form of language driven by the totality of my feeling states in what I’d like to convey. To provide a further example, think about your biggest habit. Perhaps it’s a nervous habit such as biting your nails or playing with your hair. As the frequency of these actions increase, you’ll soon realize that your hands are suddenly brought to your mouth more often. The neural pathways consistent with this activity become strengthened to such a degree that their aggregated signal is strong enough to sear this behavior into habitualization. For an undesirable habit, the behavior will continue until it crosses the individual’s fringe of consciousness, where he becomes conscious of the habit, and dismisses it. You can easily recognize yourself biting your nails, but consider ideas to work in the same way. Certainly the strength of feeling states and intentions are much more difficult to discern within our psyche. The underlying point here is that the ego is the part of our being which realizes the action and may take accountability for the action, but the belief of it driving the action is a foolish one.

We naturally identify with our conscious self, for it is the part of us we ‘see.’ However, we must understand though, that our ego is an illusory persona given to us by our brain. In neuroscience, the ego construct can be viewed as our particularly construed resting state networks (RMNs). Sub-networks within this domain include the Default Mode Network (DMN), which deals with self-reference, emotional reflection, autobiographical self-understanding, among other things. It serves as a comparative interpretation mechanism one uses to qualify one’s position in society by differentiation/dissection. Because, through evolution, a brain wired to optimize fitness was selected for, our interpretations are culturally based, and universally competitive. The pride of a currently held ideology (with which we identify) trumps the willingness to work together to get at a deeper, more unifying truth. This is because truth is relative to a group, and different groups precipitate from differentiating truths. Again, if we see that truths resonate, it is clear why groups harmonize within and clash without. Jonathan Haidt’s work on morality shows this, as we realize that truth is whatever is subjectively convincing at one’s current level of perception. At lower levels of consciousness (awareness), propositions are accepted as true, even when they are illogical. They express tenets neither intellectually provable nor practically demonstrable. Regardless, man will defend his position, however ignorant it may be.

Unfortunately as a resulting happenstance, Ego becomes God to people. Even more tragically, when ego drops, one can see the cosmic comedy of that relationship. The tragedy here is that the egocentric veil rarely drops in modern society. Ironically, the one experience of transcendence – beyond an egocentric self – which sits in absolute certainty, is the experience that also sits in a medium certain to catch everybody’s prejudices. To attempt to make oneself understood is impossible without far-reaching comprehension of another’s standpoint. Perhaps a future energetic discourse that transcends language could do it, but that’s neither here nor there. The atheist, without an empathic resonance of such an experience, discounts it.

> “A necessity for the eradication of the incommensurability between observer and observed is needed. A “neural language.”

 as W. Pauli mentions. The fear that prevents most from experiencing such transcendence is the fear of lost control. As humans, control is the thing we hold most dear to our heart. Imagining a life as a schizophrenic with no control over his actions is the worst nightmare possible for many. We take solace in the feeling of control the ego brings. Unfortunately egoic control is illusory, though one can *choose* to hold onto it. Our memories are constructed to fit a story, i.e., the memories our ego maintains to define who it thinks it is. This creates bias. Turning off memory allows highest clarity of sight. We think we are our story, and we identify with it as such. This is why the common paradigm of thought believes that the death of the ego is the death of the individual. The death one’s legacy to die must necessarily kill the man too. Anyone who has experienced an ego death – a profound spiritual experience – knows this is not the case, and the feeling of liberation from ego is ineffably beautiful.

We can look to the psychologically defined ‘insightful vs. analytic’ personal method of thinking to explain this rift between rationalists and spirituals. Insightfuls are less ‘loud’ in the mind, while considering possibilities. Analytics use ‘outsight’ where the loudest, obvious, quicker responses are reported. For a lot of day to day life, simple ‘outsight/analysis’ works. Analytics think linearly from front to back and vice versa. They also hold a tighter ‘cognitive control.’ Insightfuls think more laterally. The rationalist is the out-sighted analyst. He grips onto the self so tightly, as to surrender any other possible option. The spiritual is the insightful. Insight is derived from intuition and is the result of an understanding of the inner nature of things. With less weight on cognitive control and a more lateralized method of thought, these individuals are capable of undergoing a psychological appreciation of the fact that man is the victim of his conscious constitution more than he is the creator. To understand individuality is puppeted by a higher power still gives you a larger part in the play. But for the atheists the higher power is exclusively in ego, and stops at the State.

We can recognize prejudice and illusion only when we’re capable of taking a step back and looking back into the absolutism of our tenets, to objectively compare them with facts, while not producing an egocentric rationale as to why our conclusion is ‘still right.’ I have personally had conversations with friends where I fell victim to the same fallacy. I would notice that in discourse, one of us would realize he may be incorrect in the argument, and a subconscious transition in topic would occur, as to preserve the ego in admitting fault. This takes a great deal of awareness and mostly goes unnoticed. Donald Trump for example, is a master eluder who systematically transitions conversation once he realizes facts stack up against him, and one may say his ego is *slightly* larger than the layperson.

**Unconscious Mind**

I’d like to elucidate the unbeknownst benefit of egolessness with the following quote:

> “Anyone who has insight into his own actions, and has thus found access to the unconscious, involuntarily exercises an influence on his environment. The deepening and broadening of consciousness produce the kind of effect which the primitives call “mana.” It is a sort of unintentional influence on the unconscious of others, a sort of unconscious prestige, and its effect lasts only so long as it is not disturbed by conscious intention.”

The quote by Jung explicates the prestige gifted upon ego absence. The Taoists call this power Wu-wei, in which De is the electromagnetic signature. In this state of being, there is no thought, as one is immersed in passion/love/oneness. Whilst in this state, the unconscious elicits a harmonious, attractive pattern, which can be perceived by others. This De signature is an ode of Truth. A sign of genuine character (unconsciously spoken), yet vibrated and perceived in the environment, often under the threshold of consciousness in another. Additionally, De *comes* from the unconscious, as do our virtues, which we consciously download as they’re considered. Taoist texts explain how “the universe works harmoniously according to its own ways. When someone exerts their will against the world in a manner that is out of rhythm with the cycles of change, they may disrupt that harmony, and unintended consequences may more likely result rather than the willed outcome.” We know this as ego, though Taoists don’t explicitly connote ego. Rather, they assert that one must just “place their will in harmony with the natural universe.” That is, to align true meaning with our actions, not to perform an action which promotes solely egoic prosperity. Wu-Wei is the method of achieving this. It is a form of “trying not to try” coined by Edward G. Slingerland. Buddhists call this state of spontaneity/nothingness ‘Sunyata.’ In Buddhist traditions “desire not to desire” is more fitting. The concept is the same, and logicians are left baffled altogether.

As mentioned earlier, Westerners are starting to come to the same psychological conclusion with the phenomenon we call ‘flow,’ coined by Mihály Csíkszentmihályi. In flow states, the seer and the doer merge. The observing consciousness and experiencing consciousness commune, and the driving force behind its creation is passion, for it wields “the capacity to narrow our focus so spectacularly, as to reduce the entirety of the world to the object of our desire.” Terrence McKenna alluded to the same idea in one of his talks, in which he stated:

> “What I see is that the carrier of the field [of the cosmic giggle] in most people’s lives, is love. Love is some kind of output which messes with the entropic tendency toward probabilistic behavior in nature.”

 We see love is the most potent and harmonic awareness one can have, and it brings people the furthest. Any exceptional athlete will tell you it was his passion that drove him. Underlying it all we see that humans gain a vitality. It is vitality, that life force, which gets you furthest. And it’s derived from love. Whether it’s in the form of intellectual truth, lifelong courtship, or any form of flow in between. It’s what drives us, keeps us alive and in good health. If you lose it, you lose life. This is the idea of the soul. The Chinese call it ‘Qi,’ the Indians ‘Prana,’ the Polynesians ‘Mana,’ the Amerindians ‘Orenda,’ and the ancient Germans ‘Od.’

**Synchronicity**

Let’s talk about Jung and Pauli’s theory of synchronicity as an acausal connecting principle. Please make note of the distinction between synchrony, which deals with temporal coherence of events, and synchronicity, which deals specifically with external events coinciding with internal states in a way which creates a meaningful connection. Jung stated:
