Cola received special care from a clinic in Bangkok. The clinic team gave Cola ample time to recover before pressing onward with plans to outfit him with prosthetic limbs. While at the clinic, Cola’s owner decided to leave him under their care, as he feared taking Cola home where his neighbor still lived.

The neighbor who attacked Cola was given a month of jail time. I know, it’s not entirely fitting of the crime. But had this same incident happened only two years ago, the attacker would not have served any jail time at all. Thailand only just passed its first ever Animal Welfare Law back in 2014.

But the story has a happy ending. Co-founder of Soi Dog Foundation (the organization who paid for Cola’s recovery), Gill Dalley, decided to adopt Cola and take him back to Phuket. As fate would have it, Gill uses prosthetic limbs herself after losing both of her legs attempting to save a dog about 10 years ago.

You can learn more about Cola and Gill’s story, as well as donate to help more dogs like Cola, here:

Donate | Facebook | Gill’s Story

posts.title: People Are Being Paid to Use Electricity in Germany, Due to Renewable Energy
posts.markdown: If you’re living in a developed country right now, there’s a good chance that you own a fair amount of electronic equipment, from cellphones and tablets to entertainment centers to kitchen appliances.  Doesn’t make the energy bill very cheap if you’re running an energy-intensive operation. Germany recently had somewhat of a miracle occur, as **[Quartz reports](http://qz.com/680661/germany-had-so-much-renewable-energy-on-sunday-that-it-had-to-pay-people-to-use-electricity/)**.  On a beautiful sunny day, the country’s solar and wind power sectors had unusually high yields in energy production.   On May 8, the country’s renewable energy supply was sitting at around 55 gigawatts, with about 63 gigawatts being consumed; meaning 87 percent of the country’s energy consumption was provided by renewable energy sources. Once you add in the country’s regular supply of power from power plants, the final energy output far exceeds national demand.  Due to the brief surplus in energy, prices had actually fallen into the negative, meaning customers were actually being paid to consume energy. ![](http://cdn.iflscience.com/legacy/sites/www.iflscience.com/files/blog/2016-05/ag.png#overlay-context=health-and-medicine/brazilian-zika-virus-observed-directly-causing-brain-cell-death) *Consumers were being paid to buy energy. [Agora Energiewende](https://www.agora-energiewende.de/en/topics/-agothem-/Produkt/produkt/76/Agorameter/)* And while this is undoubtedly a great feat, Germany is not the first to experience such an occurrence.  Last year, **[Denmark’s wind sector](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/jul/10/denmark-wind-windfarm-power-exceed-electricity-demand)** generated about 140 percent of the nation’s energy demands, and subsequently had to export a portion of it to Germany, Norway and **[Sweden](http://www.iflscience.com/environment/sweden-combats-climate-change-aiming-be-fossil-fuel-free-nation/)**. A **[United Nations report](https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/index.php?page=view&type=99&nr=24&menu=1449)**shows that Germany plans to be at the forefront of renewable energy, pledging to be powered solely by renewable energy sources by the year 2050.   This is definitely a trend in the right direction and should be a goal for every country seeking to help reduce the global reliance on fossil fuels.  The **[International Energy Agency](http://www.iflscience.com/environment/one-quarter-world-will-be-powered-renewable-energy-2020/)** recently stated that over a quarter of the world will be powered by renewable energy by 2020, implying **[a shift toward nuclear and renewable energy sources](http://www.iflscience.com/environment/global-reliance-fossil-fuels-could-end-within-just-decade/).**
posts.html:
If you’re living in a developed country right now, there’s a good chance that you own a fair amount of electronic equipment, from cellphones and tablets to entertainment centers to kitchen appliances.  Doesn’t make the energy bill very cheap if you’re running an energy-intensive operation.

Germany recently had somewhat of a miracle occur, as Quartz reports.  On a beautiful sunny day, the country’s solar and wind power sectors had unusually high yields in energy production.  

On May 8, the country’s renewable energy supply was sitting at around 55 gigawatts, with about 63 gigawatts being consumed; meaning 87 percent of the country’s energy consumption was provided by renewable energy sources.

Once you add in the country’s regular supply of power from power plants, the final energy output far exceeds national demand.  Due to the brief surplus in energy, prices had actually fallen into the negative, meaning customers were actually being paid to consume energy.

Consumers were being paid to buy energy. Agora Energiewende

And while this is undoubtedly a great feat, Germany is not the first to experience such an occurrence.  Last year, Denmark’s wind sector generated about 140 percent of the nation’s energy demands, and subsequently had to export a portion of it to Germany, Norway and Sweden.

A United Nations report shows that Germany plans to be at the forefront of renewable energy, pledging to be powered solely by renewable energy sources by the year 2050.  

This is definitely a trend in the right direction and should be a goal for every country seeking to help reduce the global reliance on fossil fuels.  The International Energy Agency recently stated that over a quarter of the world will be powered by renewable energy by 2020, implying a shift toward nuclear and renewable energy sources.

posts.title: 'Magic Mushrooms' Linked to Long-Term Personality Changes
posts.markdown: More and more promising research is coming to light as psychedelic compounds like LSD and psilocybin continue to exhibit incredible health benefits for the people taking them. Katherine A. MacLean, Ph.D., and her colleagues at Johns Hopkins University conducted two studies using psilocybin, the psychoactive ingredient in magic mushrooms, to monitor the effect it had on the participants’ personalities. They discovered that individuals who took one dose of psilocybin experienced a positive alteration in their personality characteristics that lasted longer than a year.  Furthermore, whether or not participants experienced a “mystical experience” during their psychedelic session was key to increased levels of “openness” in individuals. Those who did not have a “mystical experience” showed no long-term effects on their perceived “openness,” good or bad.  And, of the five personality dimensions, which are extroversion, neuroticism, agreeableness, conscientiousness and openness, openness was the only dimension that experienced significant change during any point of the study. “Although the present study did not directly investigate the corollary benefits of increased openness, significant increases in nearly all of the facet scores indicate the potential for improvements in aesthetic and cognitive domains,” says the study. Psilocybin can be found in number of different types of mushrooms.  It was very popular in the 1960s, known for its “mind-expanding” hallucinatory properties that promoted creativity, increased gratitude and appreciation, and increased tolerance of other people. “Nearly all of the participants in the present study regularly engaged in spiritual activities such as religious services, prayer, and meditation. It is possible that such individuals are particularly sensitive to the mystical-type effects of psilocybin, which were predictive of increases in openness,” MacLean and colleagues write, regarding self-selection bias. h/t [**MedPageNews**](http://www.medpagetoday.com/psychiatry/generalpsychiatry/28788)
posts.html:
More and more promising research is coming to light as psychedelic compounds like LSD and psilocybin continue to exhibit incredible health benefits for the people taking them.

Katherine A. MacLean, Ph.D., and her colleagues at Johns Hopkins University conducted two studies using psilocybin, the psychoactive ingredient in magic mushrooms, to monitor the effect it had on the participants’ personalities.

They discovered that individuals who took one dose of psilocybin experienced a positive alteration in their personality characteristics that lasted longer than a year.  Furthermore, whether or not participants experienced a “mystical experience” during their psychedelic session was key to increased levels of “openness” in individuals.

Those who did not have a “mystical experience” showed no long-term effects on their perceived “openness,” good or bad.  And, of the five personality dimensions, which are extroversion, neuroticism, agreeableness, conscientiousness and openness, openness was the only dimension that experienced significant change during any point of the study.

“Although the present study did not directly investigate the corollary benefits of increased openness, significant increases in nearly all of the facet scores indicate the potential for improvements in aesthetic and cognitive domains,” says the study.

Psilocybin can be found in number of different types of mushrooms.  It was very popular in the 1960s, known for its “mind-expanding” hallucinatory properties that promoted creativity, increased gratitude and appreciation, and increased tolerance of other people.

“Nearly all of the participants in the present study regularly engaged in spiritual activities such as religious services, prayer, and meditation. It is possible that such individuals are particularly sensitive to the mystical-type effects of psilocybin, which were predictive of increases in openness,” MacLean and colleagues write, regarding self-selection bias.

h/t MedPageNews

posts.title: 3 Benefits of Burning and Vaporizing Bay Leaves in the Home
posts.markdown: *Image via [**YouTube**](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kWLn7CzrnKg)* While bay leaves are often found in the spice collections of people from all over the world, these leafy greens offer powerful and healthy benefits when used outside the realm of cooking. For example: burning bay leaves releases the active compounds found within, which have been found to help kill bacterial infections, detox the body, and improve heart and lung health. They might even slow down the aging process! Here are a few great benefits that burning bay leaves in your home can provide: **They relieve anxiety, tension and fatigue** Containing compounds like cineol, pinene, and elemicin, bay leaves fill the air with a relaxed energy. They’ve even been said to produce psychedelic-like effects. To do this, take your dry bay leaf and light one if its ends on fire. Blow out the fire so that the leaf is still burning, but slowly. Then, set it on a fireproof tray or dish, and let the smoke fill your space (similar to incense). After burning the bay leaf, you should notice yourself experiencing feelings of relaxation and easiness. Your mind gains clarity, alertness and energy as your stress melts away. **It clears out the respiratory system** A lesser known benefit of bay leaves are their ability to open up any clogged airways, including in our lungs. It naturally breaks down and gets rid of mucus and phlegm that builds up in our system. To achieve these effects, do not burn the bay leaf. Instead, soak fresh bay leaves in water, or obtain bay leaf oil, and put it in a humidifier to fill the air with a bay leaf vapor that is safe to breathe in. **It helps fortify cardiovascular health** Chock-full of caffeic acid, bay leaves promote healthy capillary walls in the heart. Not to mention, caffeic acid also helps rid your body of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL), the “bad” kind of cholesterol. The best way to gain these benefits is by using the bay leaf in your cooking. Mix it in with your meals regularly and you’ll notice a definite boost in your cardiovascular health. h/t [**Sun Gazing**](http://www.sun-gazing.com/2-benefits-burning-vaporizing-bay-leaves-house/)
posts.html:
Image via YouTube

While bay leaves are often found in the spice collections of people from all over the world, these leafy greens offer powerful and healthy benefits when used outside the realm of cooking.

For example: burning bay leaves releases the active compounds found within, which have been found to help kill bacterial infections, detox the body, and improve heart and lung health. They might even slow down the aging process!

Here are a few great benefits that burning bay leaves in your home can provide:

They relieve anxiety, tension and fatigue

Containing compounds like cineol, pinene, and elemicin, bay leaves fill the air with a relaxed energy. They’ve even been said to produce psychedelic-like effects.

To do this, take your dry bay leaf and light one if its ends on fire. Blow out the fire so that the leaf is still burning, but slowly. Then, set it on a fireproof tray or dish, and let the smoke fill your space (similar to incense).

After burning the bay leaf, you should notice yourself experiencing feelings of relaxation and easiness. Your mind gains clarity, alertness and energy as your stress melts away.

It clears out the respiratory system

A lesser known benefit of bay leaves are their ability to open up any clogged airways, including in our lungs. It naturally breaks down and gets rid of mucus and phlegm that builds up in our system.

To achieve these effects, do not burn the bay leaf. Instead, soak fresh bay leaves in water, or obtain bay leaf oil, and put it in a humidifier to fill the air with a bay leaf vapor that is safe to breathe in.

It helps fortify cardiovascular health

Chock-full of caffeic acid, bay leaves promote healthy capillary walls in the heart. Not to mention, caffeic acid also helps rid your body of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL), the “bad” kind of cholesterol.

The best way to gain these benefits is by using the bay leaf in your cooking. Mix it in with your meals regularly and you’ll notice a definite boost in your cardiovascular health.

h/t Sun Gazing

posts.title: Choose a Symbol and Learn About Your Spirit Message
posts.markdown: Let your intuition guide you and pick the symbol that calls to you the most. Then learn what message it has to give you below! **Symbol 1** You need to stop going against the grain and learn how to thrive in the ebb and flow of life. Try to focus more of your attention on your life in the present moment, but don’t make impulse decisions. The next step will become clear to you if you can maintain a calm, focused demeanor. **Symbol 2** It’s time for you to start building boundaries (or values) for your life. When you create boundaries (for yourself and others) you bring structure to your life. This means accepting responsibility for the way your life is, and then getting rid of anyone or anything that does not contribute to your well being in a positive way. **Symbol 3** Choosing symbol 3 means that you’re going to be okay and are headed in the right direction. Even if it might not feel like you are, or you might have more questions than answers, know that you are being looked after by the universe. **Symbol 4** You need to forget the past and move on, so you can flourish in the present moment. While there is definitely value in grieving and healing, there is absolutely no benefit in dwelling on events that have passed. Sort through your past wounds and emotions, and then let them go so you can move forward. **Symbol 5** This means that your life is moving fast in the right direction. You’re picking up momentum as your charge forward, so now is the perfect time to think about setting new goals for yourself. Do some soul-searching and figure out what it is you truly want out of life, and then chase after it! **Symbol 6** You’re probably too concerned with the outside world, and not concerned enough with your inner self. You’re likely confused, cluttered and unsure. So, take some time to disconnect. Clear your head. Go for a walk outside, meditate or do some yoga. Observe the thoughts you have, but do not judge them. Get back to your core being. **Symbol 7** Your hard work should be rewarded with some well-deserved play time. Be sure to make time in your life for a spontaneous adventure, whether it be a day-hike through the mountains, or taking a trip overseas. Do not feel guilty in letting go; enjoy life to its fullest. Eat good food, enjoy good company, and love as much as you can. **Symbol 8** You need to make time to connect with the world around you; to yourself, your friends and family, and with nature. Take off any guises or masks that you regularly put on when going about your day and work on tuning into the massive web of the universe. Connecting with yourself first, work outward, first focusing on your surroundings, and then focusing on the people in your life. Think about the best possible good you can bring to every situation. **Symbol 9** This symbol is telling you that you’ve accomplished all of the hard work you set out to do, and can now reap what you have sown. You’ve planted the seeds of growth, and are now fully aware in your wisdom. You understand that in life, there is nothing inherently good or bad; everything exists to show you how to grow, how to teach, and how to love. You should try spreading your knowledge to the world, so that others can reach the same level of awareness that you have. h/t [**Forever Conscious**](http://foreverconscious.com/intuitive-reading-pick-a-symbol-to-reveal-your-spirit-message)

posts.title: People Who Achieve Their Goals Share Three Mindsets, Psychologists Find
posts.markdown: We all have goals and things that we want to achieve in life. The problem that many of us face when trying to achieve these goals is that we’re not exactly sure how to go about doing it. For example: a person who lives a mostly sedentary lifestyle can want to transform his or herself into an athlete, but unless they know how to start that change, the chances of them achieving their goal are close to zero. These are three things that successful people keep on their minds when they’re working toward achieving their goals: **Don’t let your internal dialogue turn negative** In a world that is chock-full of seemingly extraordinary people, it can be hard to think that you will ever be one of them. As humans, we have a somewhat strange obsession with people who achieve at the highest level. One unfortunate psychological problem with this obsession is that if we are not already exceptional or extraordinary at something, we think that it’s not worth it to try. This is called having a “**[fixed mindset](http://qz.com/587811/stanford-professor-who-pioneered-praising-effort-sees-false-praise-everywhere/)**.” To overcome the attitude that you will never amount to anything great, you need to have a “growth mindset.” A growth mindset is entirely focused on your understanding that you will not become great immediately. It is recognizing that you will *eventually* achieve greatness once you start working toward it. **[Starting anything new is hard](https://www.youcubed.org/think-it-up/mistakes-grow-brain/)**, so don’t get discouraged if it’s difficult at first; it’s supposed to be. **Find others who are doing what you are doing** One of the biggest hurdles to get over when starting something new is feeling uncomfortable or like you don’t belong. The best way to overcome these feelings of awkwardness is to find a community of people that are doing the exact same thing as you. If you want to get into trail running, find a group of people who like to run together for fun. It works for *anything*. The easiest way to commit (and stay committed) to something is by thinking about the types of people you want to spend your time with. Start by yourself, but then work toward finding like-minded people to hang out with if you’re struggling to commit to your goals. **Think about who you want to be in the future** Do you ever think about**[who you want to be in five years](http://www.education.com/reference/article/possible-selves-theory/)**? If you have goals and grand visions of your future, one of the best aids in making those visions become reality is by becoming invested in the vision itself. You might have a big goal set for yourself, something like, “I want to complete a 5K sometime this year.” Great, now work on creating smaller goals that are much easier to achieve than a 5K, but that will help you progress toward your goal. Something like, “I will run at least one time in the next three days.” Imagine yourself gliding along on your legs, absolutely crushing the 5K you wanted to run. Build that image of who you want to be, and get excited about it. The more you work toward your vision of your future self, the easier it becomes to do the work, and the faster those dreams turn into reality. Don’t ever think that you cannot do something or are incapable of becoming the person you envision yourself to be in your mind. Once you understand that it’s all in your head, you can learn to use your mind to push yourself farther than you’ve ever gone before. Change your attitude, change your mindset, change your life. h/t [**QZ**](http://qz.com/751115/psychology-has-identified-three-mindsets-shared-by-people-who-actually-follow-through-on-their-goals/)
posts.html:
We all have goals and things that we want to achieve in life. The problem that many of us face when trying to achieve these goals is that we’re not exactly sure how to go about doing it.

For example: a person who lives a mostly sedentary lifestyle can want to transform his or herself into an athlete, but unless they know how to start that change, the chances of them achieving their goal are close to zero.

These are three things that successful people keep on their minds when they’re working toward achieving their goals:

Don’t let your internal dialogue turn negative

In a world that is chock-full of seemingly extraordinary people, it can be hard to think that you will ever be one of them. As humans, we have a somewhat strange obsession with people who achieve at the highest level. One unfortunate psychological problem with this obsession is that if we are not already exceptional or extraordinary at something, we think that it’s not worth it to try.

This is called having a “fixed mindset.” To overcome the attitude that you will never amount to anything great, you need to have a “growth mindset.” A growth mindset is entirely focused on your understanding that you will not become great immediately. It is recognizing that you will eventually achieve greatness once you start working toward it.

Starting anything new is hard, so don’t get discouraged if it’s difficult at first; it’s supposed to be.

Find others who are doing what you are doing

One of the biggest hurdles to get over when starting something new is feeling uncomfortable or like you don’t belong. The best way to overcome these feelings of awkwardness is to find a community of people that are doing the exact same thing as you. If you want to get into trail running, find a group of people who like to run together for fun. It works for anything.

The easiest way to commit (and stay committed) to something is by thinking about the types of people you want to spend your time with. Start by yourself, but then work toward finding like-minded people to hang out with if you’re struggling to commit to your goals.

Think about who you want to be in the future

Do you ever think about who you want to be in five years? If you have goals and grand visions of your future, one of the best aids in making those visions become reality is by becoming invested in the vision itself.

You might have a big goal set for yourself, something like, “I want to complete a 5K sometime this year.” Great, now work on creating smaller goals that are much easier to achieve than a 5K, but that will help you progress toward your goal. Something like, “I will run at least one time in the next three days.”

Imagine yourself gliding along on your legs, absolutely crushing the 5K you wanted to run. Build that image of who you want to be, and get excited about it. The more you work toward your vision of your future self, the easier it becomes to do the work, and the faster those dreams turn into reality.

Don’t ever think that you cannot do something or are incapable of becoming the person you envision yourself to be in your mind. Once you understand that it’s all in your head, you can learn to use your mind to push yourself farther than you’ve ever gone before. Change your attitude, change your mindset, change your life.

h/t QZ

posts.title: One Minute of Exercise: Is That All We Really Need?
posts.markdown: One Minute of Exercise Might Be All You Need Research Says: One Minute of Exercise Just as Good For You as 45 Minutes of Exercise As if straight out of a late-night infomercial, new research is suggesting that just one minute of intense exercise can improve health just as effectively as 45 minutes of moderate exercise activity. Can you imagine getting a full workout in in just one minute? That’s about as long as it takes to walk the trash out to the trash can or microwave some leftovers. How’d they do it? Researchers [studied nine men](http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article/asset?id=10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0154075.PDF) who lead predominantly sedentary lifestyles by having them do an entire minute of high-intensity cycling at least three times a week for 12 weeks. The minute of high-intensity cycling was broken down into three 20-second intervals where each subject was to put forth their maximum effort for the whole 20 seconds. Then, they did a two-minute recovery period with only moderate-intensity cycling in between each 20-second burst. A second group of 10 men were tasked with performing what you’d consider an average workout regimen, consisting of 45-minute sessions of non-stop, moderate-intensity cycling at least three times a week. As a control group, researchers had six men do absolutely no exercising over the course of 12 weeks. What they found after the 12 weeks were up was quite interesting. The high-intensity, short-interval group had made similar gains to the normal, moderate-intensity group. Both showed improved blood sugar levels, endurance and muscle function when compared to the control group that did not exercise. “[This study](http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article/asset?id=10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0154075.PDF) is a relatively extreme example that shows the effectiveness of brief, very intense bursts of exercise,” said Martin J. Gibala, professor of kinesiology at McMaster University in Ontario. It should be noted that the high-intensity, short-interval training method is about as quick of a workout that you can do, taking a total of 10 minutes. Two minutes of warmup on the bike, then a 20-second high intensity burst, followed by 2 minutes of recovery time after each burst interval until you end with a three-minute, moderate-intensity cooldown. Over the last decade, [there has been a heightened interest](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17991697) in the effectiveness of high-intensity training programs when compared to traditional models of exercise. Other studies have found similar results as this one, suggesting that high-intensity training is similarly effective. However, this study was the first to achieve such results with a total of only 10 minutes of exercise. http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/23/health/one-minute-workout/
posts.html:
One Minute of Exercise Might Be All You Need

Research Says: One Minute of Exercise Just as Good For You as 45 Minutes of Exercise

As if straight out of a late-night infomercial, new research is suggesting that just one minute of intense exercise can improve health just as effectively as 45 minutes of moderate exercise activity.

Can you imagine getting a full workout in in just one minute? That’s about as long as it takes to walk the trash out to the trash can or microwave some leftovers.

How’d they do it? Researchers studied nine men who lead predominantly sedentary lifestyles by having them do an entire minute of high-intensity cycling at least three times a week for 12 weeks.

The minute of high-intensity cycling was broken down into three 20-second intervals where each subject was to put forth their maximum effort for the whole 20 seconds. Then, they did a two-minute recovery period with only moderate-intensity cycling in between each 20-second burst.

A second group of 10 men were tasked with performing what you’d consider an average workout regimen, consisting of 45-minute sessions of non-stop, moderate-intensity cycling at least three times a week.

As a control group, researchers had six men do absolutely no exercising over the course of 12 weeks.

What they found after the 12 weeks were up was quite interesting. The high-intensity, short-interval group had made similar gains to the normal, moderate-intensity group. Both showed improved blood sugar levels, endurance and muscle function when compared to the control group that did not exercise.

“This study is a relatively extreme example that shows the effectiveness of brief, very intense bursts of exercise,” said Martin J. Gibala, professor of kinesiology at McMaster University in Ontario.

It should be noted that the high-intensity, short-interval training method is about as quick of a workout that you can do, taking a total of 10 minutes. Two minutes of warmup on the bike, then a 20-second high intensity burst, followed by 2 minutes of recovery time after each burst interval until you end with a three-minute, moderate-intensity cooldown.

Over the last decade, there has been a heightened interest in the effectiveness of high-intensity training programs when compared to traditional models of exercise. Other studies have found similar results as this one, suggesting that high-intensity training is similarly effective. However, this study was the first to achieve such results with a total of only 10 minutes of exercise.

http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/23/health/one-minute-workout/

posts.title: 3 Things That Make Introverts Healthier Than Everyone Else
posts.markdown: Us introverts catch a bad rap from time to time for our anti-social behaviors, but it turns out that we actually benefit from a few things that are extroverted counterparts do not. **You have a decreased risk for obesity** Studies have discovered that introverts rely more heavily on cues from the body, meaning they’re more aware of what’s going on inside. Because of this, introverts also tend to listen to what their bodies are telling them more, which means they’re less likely to keep stuffing their face once they’re full. Research conducted by the **[Cornell Food and Brand Lab](http://foodpsychology.cornell.edu/research/extraverted-children-are-more-biased-bowl-sizes-introverts)** gave children a large breakfast bowl for which to fill with cereal. Extroverts took almost 33 percent more cereal than introverts did, because they were focused on an external cue (the size of the bowl), rather than an internal cue (how hungry they actually were). **You probably get more rest** **[A study](http://www.aasmnet.org/articles.aspx?id=1944)** published in *SLEEP* journal found that extroverted tendencies lead more people to experience a lack of sleep. But, it is not so much about how often people go out, but rather the traits of their personalities. In extroverts, the areas of the brain that make them alert are also the same ones that cause fatigue the day after. Introverts already experience high levels of cortical arousal in these areas of the brain, so they’re pretty much immune to the fatigue. **Your senses are tuned a bit finer** Because introverts experience such high levels of cortical arousal (or brain activity), they are usually quite a bit more sensitive to the happenings of their surroundings. Lights, sounds, smells–they’re all amplified, so you can see why social settings or crowded environments overwhelm them. But, **[it’s not necessarily a bad thing](http://www.purewow.com/wellness/how-introverts-channel-creativity)**. At least you know exactly what you’re comfortable with.
posts.html:
Us introverts catch a bad rap from time to time for our anti-social behaviors, but it turns out that we actually benefit from a few things that are extroverted counterparts do not.

You have a decreased risk for obesity

Studies have discovered that introverts rely more heavily on cues from the body, meaning they’re more aware of what’s going on inside. Because of this, introverts also tend to listen to what their bodies are telling them more, which means they’re less likely to keep stuffing their face once they’re full.

Research conducted by the Cornell Food and Brand Lab gave children a large breakfast bowl for which to fill with cereal. Extroverts took almost 33 percent more cereal than introverts did, because they were focused on an external cue (the size of the bowl), rather than an internal cue (how hungry they actually were).

You probably get more rest

A study published in SLEEP journal found that extroverted tendencies lead more people to experience a lack of sleep. But, it is not so much about how often people go out, but rather the traits of their personalities. In extroverts, the areas of the brain that make them alert are also the same ones that cause fatigue the day after.

Introverts already experience high levels of cortical arousal in these areas of the brain, so they’re pretty much immune to the fatigue.

Your senses are tuned a bit finer

Because introverts experience such high levels of cortical arousal (or brain activity), they are usually quite a bit more sensitive to the happenings of their surroundings. Lights, sounds, smells–they’re all amplified, so you can see why social settings or crowded environments overwhelm them.

But, it’s not necessarily a bad thing. At least you know exactly what you’re comfortable with.

posts.title: The Top 10 Things You Will Regret Later in Life
posts.markdown: As humans, we, just like all other life on this planet, come with an expiration date. We know that we have a limited amount of time on Earth. Yet, so many people choose to live their lives unhappy; living a certain way for others, never pursuing their passions, never taking chances that could have changed their lives for the better. But, it’s not easy. Not everyone has the courage to build the life they dream of. It can be hard to take those first steps toward living a life that you can be proud of. So, the least you can do is be aware of what people regret the most once their time is nearing its end. **Not seeing the world** Traveling is something that everyone wants to do, even if they don’t know it. The hard part is that it can be incredibly expensive. The older we get, the less time we usually have due to other responsibilities, like a family. **Staying in a toxic relationship** Have you ever had to end a toxic relationship? Anyone who has knows that it was the right choice and that they should have done it sooner. **Not using sunscreen** People who have healthy skin through old age don’t just have it by chance. Using sunscreen helps reduce wrinkles, moles and the risk of skin cancer. **Caring too much about others’ opinions of yourself** 20 years from now, do you really think you’re going to care about what others had to say about you back then? No, you won’t be thinking about them at all. **Too much time spent working** When you’re lying on your deathbed, do you think you’ll miss spending time at work, or spending time with the people you love the most in this world? **Never taking risks, in life and in love** For most people, there’s always at least one thing they wanted to do, but didn’t out of fear of failure or rejection. When you’re old, you’ll be happy that you at least tried, even if you failed spectacularly. **Not showing gratitude sooner** It might not seem like it right now, but one day it will all start to click: every second that we spend on this planet is precious, and we’re lucky to be able to share this experience with others. **Placing others’ dreams before your own** Being supportive of your friends and family members is a good thing. It becomes a bad thing when your own dreams and well being start to fall on the back-burner to make time for someone else’s. **Not being physically active** For many people, sitting around on the couch is their favorite pastime. But it is likely to be something they regret once they reach 40, 50, or 60. Run, jump, play and compete while you can. One day, you’ll only dream of doing so. **Not finishing what you started / Pursuing a passion** So many people start things that they never finish. It could be nursing school, an art project, or some grand business venture. Don’t wake up one day wishing you had just *done* what you wanted to do. Do it now.
posts.html:
As humans, we, just like all other life on this planet, come with an expiration date. We know that we have a limited amount of time on Earth. Yet, so many people choose to live their lives unhappy; living a certain way for others, never pursuing their passions, never taking chances that could have changed their lives for the better.

But, it’s not easy. Not everyone has the courage to build the life they dream of. It can be hard to take those first steps toward living a life that you can be proud of. So, the least you can do is be aware of what people regret the most once their time is nearing its end.

Not seeing the world

Traveling is something that everyone wants to do, even if they don’t know it. The hard part is that it can be incredibly expensive. The older we get, the less time we usually have due to other responsibilities, like a family.

Staying in a toxic relationship

Have you ever had to end a toxic relationship? Anyone who has knows that it was the right choice and that they should have done it sooner.

Not using sunscreen

People who have healthy skin through old age don’t just have it by chance. Using sunscreen helps reduce wrinkles, moles and the risk of skin cancer.

Caring too much about others’ opinions of yourself

20 years from now, do you really think you’re going to care about what others had to say about you back then? No, you won’t be thinking about them at all.

Too much time spent working

When you’re lying on your deathbed, do you think you’ll miss spending time at work, or spending time with the people you love the most in this world?

Never taking risks, in life and in love

For most people, there’s always at least one thing they wanted to do, but didn’t out of fear of failure or rejection. When you’re old, you’ll be happy that you at least tried, even if you failed spectacularly.

Not showing gratitude sooner

It might not seem like it right now, but one day it will all start to click: every second that we spend on this planet is precious, and we’re lucky to be able to share this experience with others.

Placing others’ dreams before your own

Being supportive of your friends and family members is a good thing. It becomes a bad thing when your own dreams and well being start to fall on the back-burner to make time for someone else’s.

Not being physically active

For many people, sitting around on the couch is their favorite pastime. But it is likely to be something they regret once they reach 40, 50, or 60. Run, jump, play and compete while you can. One day, you’ll only dream of doing so.

Not finishing what you started / Pursuing a passion

So many people start things that they never finish. It could be nursing school, an art project, or some grand business venture. Don’t wake up one day wishing you had just done what you wanted to do. Do it now.

posts.title: This is What Happens When You Stop Drinking Coffee and Alcohol for Over a Year
posts.markdown: Ever wonder what your life would be like if you suddenly dropped some of the habits that you do regularly? As a person who drinks coffee pretty much every morning, the notion can be a tough one to stomach. Maybe even more so for the person who enjoys having a few beers every night after work or on the weekends when it’s play time. But a lot can change in your life by cutting out certain habits. If you’ve been thinking about making a change, here’s one person’s account of the things that changed for them after ditching coffee and alcohol completely: **You’ll save quite a bit of money** Have you ever thought about how pricey alcoholic beverages can be? I mean, I had two tacos and a beer tonight for dinner; the beer cost me $3.50 and the tacos cost me $8. I can buy a whole six-pack of beer for $9. If you regularly go out and spend money on drinks, whether it’s at a bar or a restaurant, you’re likely paying quite a bit to consume that alcohol. Cocktails easily reach up to $10 a piece, with beers ranging around $4 to $5 each. Even if you you spend only $10 a day on alcohol, that’s $300 a month. Not to mention, people rarely just drink. They get food and appetizers to go with it. Before you know it, all of these things add up, and you’re spending thousands of dollars. **Less social drama** If you’re not drinking as often, you’re probably not going out as often. Cutting alcohol out of your diet means quite a few things in the social world. One, you’re going to have to explain to people why you’re not drinking and that not even having one drink is okay with you. Two, you probably won’t want to go out as much, and you’ll want to hear about social gossip even less. Three, you’re not going to want to hang out with a bunch of drunk people while you’re sober for very long. Lastly, you’ll quickly realize how many of your friendships were based entirely on your shared passion for getting drunk. **You’ll sleep better** Quality of sleep is a very real thing, and it’s not just about how fast you can fall asleep. Sure, having a glass of wine or two will help you doze off into la-la land fairly fast, but how well are you sleeping once you doze off? And how well do you feel in the mornings? Quitting alcohol makes waking up easier and gives you more energy during your days. **Less coffee, less anxiety** While this point should be taken on a case-by-case basis, coffee is not for everyone. I used to never drink coffee and I was fine. I drink coffee now, and I’m fine. But for a lot of people the caffeine can lead to increased bouts of anxiety and difficulty with digestion. If you’ve been thinking about ditching coffee, do it. If you love the taste and smell, grab your favorite decaf and snack on that when you get a craving. For many of us, coffee is a social activity, just like alcohol. Make sure you’re not just drinking stuff so you can hang out with your friends. h/t [**HuffingtonPost**](http://www.huffingtonpost.com/tobias-van-schneider/no-alcohol-no-coffee-for-15-months-this-is-what-happened_b_8723958.html)
posts.html:
Ever wonder what your life would be like if you suddenly dropped some of the habits that you do regularly? As a person who drinks coffee pretty much every morning, the notion can be a tough one to stomach. Maybe even more so for the person who enjoys having a few beers every night after work or on the weekends when it’s play time.

But a lot can change in your life by cutting out certain habits. If you’ve been thinking about making a change, here’s one person’s account of the things that changed for them after ditching coffee and alcohol completely:

You’ll save quite a bit of money

Have you ever thought about how pricey alcoholic beverages can be? I mean, I had two tacos and a beer tonight for dinner; the beer cost me $3.50 and the tacos cost me $8. I can buy a whole six-pack of beer for $9.

If you regularly go out and spend money on drinks, whether it’s at a bar or a restaurant, you’re likely paying quite a bit to consume that alcohol.

Cocktails easily reach up to $10 a piece, with beers ranging around $4 to $5 each. Even if you you spend only $10 a day on alcohol, that’s $300 a month. Not to mention, people rarely just drink. They get food and appetizers to go with it.

Before you know it, all of these things add up, and you’re spending thousands of dollars.

Less social drama

If you’re not drinking as often, you’re probably not going out as often. Cutting alcohol out of your diet means quite a few things in the social world.

One, you’re going to have to explain to people why you’re not drinking and that not even having one drink is okay with you. Two, you probably won’t want to go out as much, and you’ll want to hear about social gossip even less. Three, you’re not going to want to hang out with a bunch of drunk people while you’re sober for very long.

Lastly, you’ll quickly realize how many of your friendships were based entirely on your shared passion for getting drunk.

You’ll sleep better

Quality of sleep is a very real thing, and it’s not just about how fast you can fall asleep. Sure, having a glass of wine or two will help you doze off into la-la land fairly fast, but how well are you sleeping once you doze off? And how well do you feel in the mornings?

Quitting alcohol makes waking up easier and gives you more energy during your days.

Less coffee, less anxiety

While this point should be taken on a case-by-case basis, coffee is not for everyone. I used to never drink coffee and I was fine. I drink coffee now, and I’m fine. But for a lot of people the caffeine can lead to increased bouts of anxiety and difficulty with digestion.

If you’ve been thinking about ditching coffee, do it. If you love the taste and smell, grab your favorite decaf and snack on that when you get a craving.

For many of us, coffee is a social activity, just like alcohol. Make sure you’re not just drinking stuff so you can hang out with your friends.

h/t HuffingtonPost

posts.title: Are You a People Pleaser? (One Easy Trick to Know for Sure!)
posts.markdown: By [**Andrea Schulman**](https://www.facebook.com/raiseyourvibrationtoday/?fref=ts) | [**Raise Your Vibration Today **](http://raiseyourvibrationtoday.com/2016/08/08/are-you-a-people-pleaser-easy-trick/) *Are you a people pleaser?* Maybe not, but I’ve found that many **[Law of Attraction](http://www.raiseyourvibrationtoday.com "Raise Your Vibration Today: Law of Attraction Education")** enthusiasts  often are! So if you are, trust you are in good company. Now I’m not sure why so many students of the LOA are people pleasers, but I have my theories. I personally believe that people who are empathic and intuitive are often drawn to the LOA, and I think this has something to do with it. Empathy and intuition often go hand-in-hand with people pleasing. After all, if you are highly sensitive, you can just “tell” when someone is upset or going through a challenging time. Naturally, you may want to help them feel better. ## People pleasing causes more harm than good! Unfortunately, people pleasing really doesn’t help anyone at all in the long run. Of course, we may be able to avoid a fight or prevent someone we care about from being upset in the moment. However, this comes at a cost to our own feelings, emotions and self-esteem. After all, if you live your life constantly adjusting how you act in order to serve others, this can cause you to feel extremely marginalized and overlooked. Your feelings and emotions are very important, after all!  When you push them down to for the sake of someone else, you set your self up for frustration, sadness or even anger down the road. Beyond that, people pleasing prevents the other people in your life from handling their own emotions and problems. It keeps them from learning to deal with the reality that other people have feelings and needs too. In a nutshell, people pleasing prevents other people from their own growth, expansion and empowerment.  ***Related Article: [Are You Energy Sensitive? 6 Telling Signs](http://raiseyourvibrationtoday.com/2015/10/20/are-you-energy-sensitive-signs/ "Are You Energy Sensitive?")*** So, what do you think: Are you a people pleaser? If so, how do you stop people pleasing? What are empathic or intuitive people to do when they are used to putting their own needs second (or third, or fourth, or seventy-fifth)? I’ve got one easy trick to help you out. Here it is: ## *Are You a People Pleaser? Easy Trick: * This is a super, super easy trick you can use at any time to evaluate if your choices and behaviors are authentic to you, and to answer the question: Are you a people pleaser? ### **How it works:** Often times, people pleasers are so used to putting their own wants and needs on the back burner that they totally forget how to act authentically around certain people! People pleasers condition themselves to always evaluate the other person first. For that reason, sometimes it’s hard to know for sure when you are people pleasing!  So this trick is helpful, because it helps you know for sure when you are people pleasing. When you aren’t sure if you are people pleasing or not, just ask yourself: “Would I do this if this person wasn’t here right now?” OR “Would I choose to do this if this person was someone else I really, truly trusted?”  Measure your behaviors against what you would choose to do if you weren’t in the company of someone you might disappoint. ### Quick example: For example, let’s say your mother has come to stay with you for the week at your house, and you worry that you often people please around her. So while she’s at your house, evaluate your behaviors.  “Would I be running around cleaning up like this if she wasn’t here?” “Would I have agreed with her opinion if she was someone I really trusted?” If you find that you are engaged in a behavior you wouldn’t do if your mother wasn’t around, you can bet your bottom dollar you are people pleasing.  You are tiptoeing around her in order to avoid getting a negative reaction.  ### *Ok, so I know I am people pleasing, but how do I stop?* You’ll find that when you use the trick above it’s pretty easy to tell if you are people pleasing. With that being said, how do you stop people pleasing? After all, sometimes it’s hard to stop people pleasing. If you’re used to turning cartwheels to please someone, it’s probably an automatic behavior by now. So here’s a quick suggestion, and it’s fairly simple: Instead of trying to stop your people pleasing, try to start your **“me pleasing”** instead*.* For example, when you are around someone you usually people please, periodically ask yourself “what might I do right now that I enjoy when I’m by myself or with someone I really trust?” Then, pick a few behaviors or activities, and throw them into the mix!  The more you choose me-pleasing behaviors, the more they will take root in your life. ### “Me Pleasing” For instance, if you would like to listen to a particular radio station, put it on.  If you would like to order ham on your pizza, order ham on your pizza. If you would like to talk about your favorite movie, strike up a conversation about it. Take a moment to identify what “me” would like to do, and as much as you can, insert these me pleasing behaviors into your interactions with others.  Let yourself off the hook for the people pleasing, but do your best to add in some me pleasing as often as you can. There’s no sense in beating yourself up when you notice that you’ve been tap dancing around your friends, family or coworkers. However, in any moment you can always ask yourself “what’s something*** I***would enjoy?” and you can add a little more personal enjoyment into the interaction. Of course, it’s always easier to start with smaller behaviors that are fairly comfortable, and work your way up. It might be a challenge to call your mom out for her shit or insist on doing something you know she’s going to hate.  Start small by pushing your comfort level a little further than usual. In time it will get easier and easier to act authentically and on your own behalf. ## Just remember… Your feelings are important. In fact, they are the most important feelings in your world. Ignore your own wants and needs and you’re setting yourself up for feeling like you always come second in your own life. It’s completely justifiable to put yourself first in your own life. In fact, it’s the best thing you can do for you, and for the world! Take care of your own needs and wants, and you’ll be better equipped to be the best person you can be. This benefits us all tremendously. If you really want to uplift the people you care about, you’ll be the greatest influence when you act from a place of strength and authenticity. XO, Andrea *(Law of Attraction coach & educator)* ### Are you a student of the Law of Attraction? Sign up for my free [Law of Attraction newsletter](http://raiseyourvibrationtoday.us9.list-manage.com/subscribe?u=36d05de151fc23b6dee2dd220&id=db39a47128 "subscribe") for conscious advice to help you attract positive outcomes into your life.  You can also become a member of my LOA member website and gain access to a library of video tutorials, ebooks, audiobooks and meditations.  Learn how to attract the things you want with fun, clarity and success!   Join today for as little as[ $1.99](https://raiseyourvibrationtoday.com/membership-checkout/?level=1 "become a member for just $1.99!") or become an annual member for [30% in savings](https://raiseyourvibrationtoday.com/membership-checkout/?level=2 "annual member"). *Article Source: This article was originally published at [Raise Your Vibration Today](http://raiseyourvibrationtoday.com/2016/08/08/are-you-a-people-pleaser-easy-trick/) and has been reposted with permission from the author.*
posts.html:
By Andrea Schulman | Raise Your Vibration Today 

Are you a people pleaser?

Maybe not, but I’ve found that many Law of Attraction enthusiasts  often are! So if you are, trust you are in good company.

Now I’m not sure why so many students of the LOA are people pleasers, but I have my theories. I personally believe that people who are empathic and intuitive are often drawn to the LOA, and I think this has something to do with it.

Empathy and intuition often go hand-in-hand with people pleasing. After all, if you are highly sensitive, you can just “tell” when someone is upset or going through a challenging time. Naturally, you may want to help them feel better.

People pleasing causes more harm than good!

Unfortunately, people pleasing really doesn’t help anyone at all in the long run. Of course, we may be able to avoid a fight or prevent someone we care about from being upset in the moment. However, this comes at a cost to our own feelings, emotions and self-esteem.

After all, if you live your life constantly adjusting how you act in order to serve others, this can cause you to feel extremely marginalized and overlooked. Your feelings and emotions are very important, after all!  When you push them down to for the sake of someone else, you set your self up for frustration, sadness or even anger down the road.

Beyond that, people pleasing prevents the other people in your life from handling their own emotions and problems. It keeps them from learning to deal with the reality that other people have feelings and needs too. In a nutshell, people pleasing prevents other people from their own growth, expansion and empowerment. 

Related Article: Are You Energy Sensitive? 6 Telling Signs

So, what do you think: Are you a people pleaser? If so, how do you stop people pleasing? What are empathic or intuitive people to do when they are used to putting their own needs second (or third, or fourth, or seventy-fifth)?

I’ve got one easy trick to help you out. Here it is:

Are You a People Pleaser? Easy Trick: 

This is a super, super easy trick you can use at any time to evaluate if your choices and behaviors are authentic to you, and to answer the question: Are you a people pleaser?

How it works:

Often times, people pleasers are so used to putting their own wants and needs on the back burner that they totally forget how to act authentically around certain people! People pleasers condition themselves to always evaluate the other person first. For that reason, sometimes it’s hard to know for sure when you are people pleasing! 

So this trick is helpful, because it helps you know for sure when you are people pleasing.

When you aren’t sure if you are people pleasing or not, just ask yourself: “Would I do this if this person wasn’t here right now?” OR “Would I choose to do this if this person was someone else I really, truly trusted?” 

Measure your behaviors against what you would choose to do if you weren’t in the company of someone you might disappoint.

Quick example:

For example, let’s say your mother has come to stay with you for the week at your house, and you worry that you often people please around her.

So while she’s at your house, evaluate your behaviors.  “Would I be running around cleaning up like this if she wasn’t here?” “Would I have agreed with her opinion if she was someone I really trusted?”

If you find that you are engaged in a behavior you wouldn’t do if your mother wasn’t around, you can bet your bottom dollar you are people pleasing.  You are tiptoeing around her in order to avoid getting a negative reaction. 

Ok, so I know I am people pleasing, but how do I stop?

You’ll find that when you use the trick above it’s pretty easy to tell if you are people pleasing. With that being said, how do you stop people pleasing?

After all, sometimes it’s hard to stop people pleasing. If you’re used to turning cartwheels to please someone, it’s probably an automatic behavior by now.

So here’s a quick suggestion, and it’s fairly simple:

Instead of trying to stop your people pleasing, try to start your “me pleasing” instead.

For example, when you are around someone you usually people please, periodically ask yourself “what might I do right now that I enjoy when I’m by myself or with someone I really trust?” Then, pick a few behaviors or activities, and throw them into the mix! 

The more you choose me-pleasing behaviors, the more they will take root in your life.

“Me Pleasing”

For instance, if you would like to listen to a particular radio station, put it on.  If you would like to order ham on your pizza, order ham on your pizza. If you would like to talk about your favorite movie, strike up a conversation about it.

Take a moment to identify what “me” would like to do, and as much as you can, insert these me pleasing behaviors into your interactions with others.  Let yourself off the hook for the people pleasing, but do your best to add in some me pleasing as often as you can.

There’s no sense in beating yourself up when you notice that you’ve been tap dancing around your friends, family or coworkers. However, in any moment you can always ask yourself “what’s something I would enjoy?” and you can add a little more personal enjoyment into the interaction.

Of course, it’s always easier to start with smaller behaviors that are fairly comfortable, and work your way up. It might be a challenge to call your mom out for her shit or insist on doing something you know she’s going to hate.  Start small by pushing your comfort level a little further than usual.

In time it will get easier and easier to act authentically and on your own behalf.

Just remember…

Your feelings are important. In fact, they are the most important feelings in your world. Ignore your own wants and needs and you’re setting yourself up for feeling like you always come second in your own life.

It’s completely justifiable to put yourself first in your own life. In fact, it’s the best thing you can do for you, and for the world!

Take care of your own needs and wants, and you’ll be better equipped to be the best person you can be. This benefits us all tremendously. If you really want to uplift the people you care about, you’ll be the greatest influence when you act from a place of strength and authenticity.

XO, Andrea

(Law of Attraction coach & educator)
